content.$t: Chrome Version : 2.0.181.0 (Developer Build 16008) OS + version : Goobuntu gHardy window manager : metacity URLs (if applicable) : https://docs.google.com/a/google.com/Edit? id=ckt2fsb_7g23j83dv (googlers: ask for access) Behavior in Firefox 3.x (if applicable): no crash. What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Navigate to Google doc in URL above 2. Edit doc 3. Possibly triggered by the auto-save?? What is the expected result? No crash. What happens instead? Browser window disappears. Various messages on console including: free() of invalid pointer, corrupted double-linked list, segfault, broken pipe. Please provide any additional information below. Attach a screenshot and backtrace if possible. Attached is a file with three console logs including stack traces.

title.$t: Dragged tab background is opaque when using a non-compositing window manager in Linux

content.$t:
A better bounding polygon region needs to be mapped for tabs.  If the check 
for a compositing WM fails, this region should be fed into 
gdk_window_shape_combine_region in order to achieve a transparent window.

title.$t: Bookmarks bar doesn't match rest of themed UI

content.$t:
It's blue but not the right blue.

(Filing this so we don't forget -- not sure which of y'all should be 
responsible for it.)

title.$t: InfoBubbleGtk (star popup bubble) needs cleanup

content.$t: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Click the star button 2. We get a bookmark bubble that says "hej!" and has a placeholder menu. We should either finish implementing this or remove it. The current implementation (as a toplevel window) looks bad on ion since it obscures the window below it.

title.$t: "Save as..." dialog nonfunctional (missing components, 100% CPU)

content.$t:
This appears to only happen on 32-bit Chrome (?).
Right click on an image and click "save as".

Contrast the Chrome screenshot versus the Firefox one.

It appears the message loop is going crazy -- repeatedly rerunning our 
dispatch, despite us properly telling it to call back later.

Vague guess, but it could be related to code in the dialog initialization 
running a nested message loop?

Not sure of the proper priority for this.  It's pretty broken.  I'm not sure 
how many others are encountering it.

title.$t: Linux: tab dragging crash

content.$t:
Drag a tab downwards. It causes a seg fault. It's not easy to get the stack
trace because if you use GDB, the crashed program stays alive and grabs all
input.

using r16458

title.$t: SessionRestore does not close the old window

content.$t: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Crash the browser 2. Open the browser 3. Click on restore What is the expected output? What do you see instead? This should restore the old browser session in a new browser window and close the old browser window. Instead, both browser windows are around. It seems to be because we don't call BrowserList::SetLastActive().

title.$t: Autocomplete painting broken?

content.$t: Chrome Version : r16609 OS + version : ghardy window manager : ion3 What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Go to a page with a text field. 2. Enter in values with similar prefixes and submit each time. Rinse, repeat. 3. Now, go back to the page. Enter the first letter. X choices pop up. As you enter more and more letters, you get fewer and fewer choices. However, the old choices still appear underneath, although you cannot highlight them.

title.$t: Closing a tab can cause the current page to disappear

content.$t: Chrome Version : 16751 OS + version : Ubuntu 9.04 window manager : GTK URLs (if applicable) : Behavior in Firefox 3.x (if applicable): What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Open several tabs and pages 2. Close any tab to the right of your current tab (closing tabs to the left doesn't do anything unexpected) What is the expected result? Tab closes, nothing else. What happens instead? Tab closes, the rendering of the current page goes away. Effect continues even when you navigate away from the current page. Please provide any additional information below. Attach a screenshot and backtrace if possible. Switching tabs causes things to go back to normal, though this really shouldn't be happening.

title.$t: LD_LIBRARY_PATH is cleared when execing SUID binaries, so it's not passed to the zygote

content.$t:
With the SUID sandbox, certain environment variables (esp LD_LIBRARY_PATH) 
are cleared for security reasons. This means that the child zygote process 
isn't run with the correct environment and can fail to start.

Need to find the list of scrubbed envvars and re-establish the environment 
for the child process.

title.$t: application/json download crashes Chrome

content.$t: Chrome Version : Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686 (x86_64); en-US) AppleWebKit/531.5 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/3.0.194.0 Safari/531.5 OS + version: Kubuntu Karmic CPU architecture (32-bit / 64-bit): 64-bit window manager : KWin URLs (if applicable) : http://db.mmo-champion.com/item/12345/json Behavior in Firefox 3.x (if applicable): Downloads the file Behavior in Chrome for Windows (optional): untested What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Go to http://db.mmo-champion.com/item/12345/json 2. Refresh/open new tab a few times. Usually takes 1-4 tries. What is the expected result? The file should either show or download. What happens instead? Chrome crashes. I'm going to guess its related to files being served as application/json, but I haven't tested anything else.

title.$t: SysTreeView of 'Cookies and Website permissions' should get keyboard focus after deleting a cookie.

content.$t:
ToT (r 31913)

User should be able to delete all the cookies one by one continuously, with
out clicking on the tree view of the Cookies and Website permissions of the
dialog.

Right now, after deleting a cookie, focus is no where and if you click on
'Remove' button again nothing happens. You have to first click on the tree
view and then click on 'Remove button'.

We should behave here we do in Win.

title.$t: [MD audit] [RPC] Integer overflow in clipboard image deserialization

content.$t:
From Mark:

---
3. Clipboard Buffer Overflow (Linux Only)

File: app/clipboard/clipboard_linux.cc
Function: Clipoard::WriteBitmap()
Problem Type: Integer Overflow
Compromise Type: Local Escalation
Severity: Medium

This can corrupt out of bounds memory when converting image data. The 
IsBitmapSafe() function has already verified that the input message is 
width * height * 
4, but obviously this can be bypassed due to an integer overflow in the 
check. The Windows version uses the CreateDIBSection system call and hence 
is 
unexploitable for this bug. Reachable via ViewHostMsg_ClipboardWrite* APIs 
over the IPC pipe.
---

title.$t: [MD audit] [clipboard] Type confusion possible in Linux clipboard implementation

content.$t:
I'll fix this right away.

Raw text from Mark:

---
2. Clipboard Arbitrary Data Format Writing (Linux)

File: app/clipboard/clipboard_linux.cc
Function: Clipoard::WriteData()
Problem Type: Logic
Compromise Type: Local Escalation
Severity: Medium
Message: ViewHostMsg_WriteObjectsAsync, ViewHostMsg_WriteObjectsSync

When writing data to the clipboard of type CBF_DATA, the untrusted renderer 
provides two strings - a format and the data itself. In the linux clipboard 
implementation, the 'format' is used as a key in to a map (clipboard_data_) 
which is then later used to set the clipboard contents. However, the user 
may supply a format that already exists (such as kMimeBmp - 
"image/bitmap"). In this case, the clipboard data will be set with an 
arbitrary set of data bytes (that is not null-terminated and has not been 
checked in any way). By reading back clipboard data of the poisoned type 
using ViwHostMsg_Read*, it is possible to have the unsanitized data 
processed with various consequences. Note that this attack cannot be 
performed on Windows since RegisterClipboardFormat() will only allow using 
user-defined clipboard types (with values in the range 0xC000 - 0xFFFF). 
However, if there were any known types in this range, the user might be 
able to cause problems with those.
---

title.$t: Memory corruption on Linux when render Khmer script page

content.$t:
There's a reliable sad-tab with M6 Beta on Linux with this page:

http://svichet.wordpress.com/

Crashes are all over the shop in the tcmalloc() allocator; looks like a nasty case of memory corruption.
I also managed to get my new tab screen into a state where it sad-tabs every visit -- I believe this is because of trying to render simply the title of this page.

I believe this is Linux specific; perhaps a bug in Harfbuzz or FontLinux.cpp. It also seems to be a regression since 5.0.375.127 (unless I'm missing some font on my laptop).

A smaller repro is attached. It's just a title, really. I get a sad tab if I open this page then hit "view source" (refresh things a few times if you get no joy). (This is with tcmalloc; unfortunately I just rebuilt without tcmalloc and it seems harder to trigger. Valgrind still mysteriously just exits even without tcmalloc).

title.$t: get mac build compiling after the merge

content.$t: Doesn't build now.

title.$t: Provide launcher icons in various sizes and png

content.$t: Chrome Version : any upcoming Linux version Other browsers tested: Add OK or FAIL after other browsers where you have tested this issue: Firefox 3: OK Chromium does only provide a 48x48 version of the icon in src/chrome/app/theme/chromium/chromium.ico The .ico file format is not supported by GNOME and KDE so for launchers we will need separate .png files of the logo in various sizes. The FreeDesktop icon spec asks for the following sizes: - 16x16 - 22x22 - 24x24 (which is 22x22 with a 1px border) - 32x32 - 48x48 (ideally availabe in scalable SVG format) - 256x256 Note that this affects both Chromium and Chrome. Chrome at least has a multi-res .ico file which contains most of the needed sizes.

title.$t: OS X: Spell check marker drawing is broken and crashy

Steps to reproduce:
* Start typing in a text area e.g. compose a new email in gmail.
* Misspell a word.

Expected results:
Underlines for misspelled words.

Actual results:

title.$t: Mac: Omnibox grabbing focus away from intended party.

content.$t:
On tab switch, AutocompleteEditViewMac::UpdateAndStyleText() is grabbing focus, but that should 
be controlled by LocationBar.

title.$t: OS X: Breakpad not dumping crash reports

content.$t:
Steps to reproduce:
* In international preferences set "עברית" to be the default system 
language.
* Launch Chrome.
* Watch Chrome silently crash (this bug is about breakpad, not the fact 
Chrome is crashing here).

Expected results:
If Chrome Crashes we should get a Minidump.

Actual results:
No Crash log is generated.
Breakpad prints the following to the console:
5/13/09 4:38:11 PM com.apple.launchd.peruser.69693[401] Breakpad 
Reporter: unable to determine minidump file length

title.$t: Eliminate all NOTIMPLEMENTEDs that aren't helpful for finding bugs

content.$t:
NOTIMPLEMENTED() is useful when you're tracking down why a given behavior is 
crashing -- they help you find code paths that haven't yet been thought 
through.  But we print so many, about unuseful stuff (like "is first run") 
they're not helpful.  It especially confuses users.

I'd prefer for a fresh run to not print any NOTIMPLEMENTED, and instead have 
bugs filed.

title.$t: regression - no webpage is rendered : blank white page seen

content.$t: Chrome version : 3.0.189.0 What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Go to any url say google.com What is the expected output? webpage should be rendered What do you see instead? webpage not rendered, blank white page seen.

title.$t: Browser process hangs with cocoa exception about images

content.$t:
- load gmail
- wait a couple seconds

It's intermittent, but fairly reproducible. In the OS console, you'll see:

Thu Jul  9 12:00:54 dhcp-172-29-45-134.her.corp.google.com Chromium[43087]
<Error>: CGImageCreate: invalid image size: 0 x 0.
2009-07-09 12:00:54.354 Chromium[43087:10b] *** Assertion failure in
-[NSBitmapImageRep initWithCGImage:],
/SourceCache/AppKit/AppKit-949.46/AppKit.subproj/NSBitmapImageRep.m:508

And then the browser process will peg at 100% cpu in the message pump. It's
unable to load pages from here on out and needs to be quit (even though you
can open new tabs, they're useless).

It's probably related to favicons and us getting a bad one somewhere and
not dealing with it correctly. Note the favicon for gmail does correctly
display in the tab. NOt sure when this regressed.

title.$t: Omnibox no longer gives the list of suggestions

content.$t: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Click in the omnibox 2. Type something 3. Fail to see a list From the buildbot's archives, build r20491 was the last one in which the omnibox worked, while in the next build, r20496, it failed. There were three changes (http://build.chromium.org/buildbot/continuous/mac/2009-07-13/20496/changelog.xml) and all were yours, shess.

title.$t: Drop down menu shows site blocking options instead of actual list of options after Chrome blocks any popup

content.$t: Platform: Hostname: RohMac-2.local Mac OS X Version 10.5.7 (Build 9J3050) Processor: 2 Intel 2.40 GHz RAM: 2048 MB Chrome: Chrome version: 3.0.194.3 <<<Release>>> QuickTime Player: 7.6.2 Flash Player: 10.0.22.87 What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Open any site A for which Chrome has to block popup. ie. http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/ 2. Open any other site B in another tab which has drop down menu. ie. bankofamerica.com 3. Verify options of drop down menu of site B. Expected result: 3.1 Drop down menu has all the options. Actual result: 3.2 Drop down menu has site blocking options. Note: - Screenshot is attached.

title.$t: Installing Classic Theme prevents Chrome from starting

content.$t: Chrome Version : 3.0.196.0 URLs (if applicable) : n/a OS version : 10.5.7 Behavior in Safari 3.x/4.x (if applicable): n/a Behavior in Firefox 3.x (if applicable): n/a Behavior in Chrome for Windows: n/a What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Click Chrome icon in dock or direct from Applications. What is the expected result? 1. Chrome launches and stays open. What happens instead? 1. Chrome icon appears in doc for milliseconds, then closes. No window opens. Extra info: I have tried removing Chrome, emptying trash, reinstalling from fresh .dmg, rebooting, etc. The last thing I remember doing in a working instance of the app was tearing off a tab to form a new window. The new window appeared without any browser chrome at all. I quit Chrome from the dock, and it has not reopened ever since.

title.$t: Breakpad-enabled build is all busted and stuff

content.$t:
While linking the framework:

ld: duplicate symbol MachMessage::CalculateSize()       in 
/chrome/trunk/src/xcodebuild/Release/libbreakpad_utilities.a(MachIPC.o) 
and /chrome/trunk/src/xcodebuild/Release/libbase.a(mach_ipc_mac.o)
collect2: ld returned 1 exit status
Command /Developer/usr/bin/g++-4.2 failed with exit code 1

This began in r35977 (bug 13156).  The MachMessage class was added to 
src/base/mach_ipc_mac.[h|mm].  In a Breakpad-enabled build, we already 
have this class present at breakpad/src/common/mac/MachIPC.[h|mm].

content.$t: Chrome Version : 4.0.302.2 (Official Build 36665) dev (Mac) URLs (if applicable) : Other browsers tested: Add OK or FAIL after other browsers where you have tested this issue: Safari 4: OK Firefox 3.x: IE 7: IE 8: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Go to amazon.com 2. Submit the search form at the top. 3. Before the next page loads, click on the drop-down to the left to open it. 4. Once the next page loads, click on the page to close the drop-down. What is the expected result? The drop down closes. What happens instead? The browser crashes Please provide any additional information below. Attach a screenshot if possible. Experienced this on on Mac OS X 10.6.2

title.$t: Zombies say: "Braaaaaaaaaiiiiiiiiiiins!"
Trouble when opening a downloadable link

content.$t:
I found this bug specifically in Chrome for Mac (4.0.249.49).

The bug happens when I try to download any file, bug instead of left-clicking 
directly the link, I middle-click it.
This causes chrome to open a new tab with the downloadable file.
A file save dialog opens briefly and closes soon after that.
If I go to the opened tab, there is nothing there. The download has vanished.
If I close the empty tab, Chrome crashes.

that is it.

title.$t: page_cycler_morejs is timing out on 10.6 perf bots

content.$t: page_cycler_morejs is timing out on 10.6 perf bots

title.$t: Running Flash in Chrome Dev Appears to be Destroying Logic Boards

content.$t:
Chrome Developer 5.0.342.1 has apparently twice destroyed my 2.5 GHz Intel
Core 2 Duo Macbook Pro running a GeForce 8600M GT NVIDIA graphics card.  

Flash games have *apparently* twice resulted in a browser crash that
required a hard reboot after which the Macbook failed to boot (in both
cases the graphics processor on the logic board was ruined).  Each case
required replacement of the logic board.

If this is a coincidence, it is an odd one indeed. I don't plan on testing
this further.  Indeed, I'm currently done running Chrome.

title.$t: I18n text drag n drop fails from Chrome to other app (like TextEdit)

content.$t: Platform: Hostname: RohMac-2.local Mac OS X Version 10.5.8 (Build 9L30) Processor: 2 Intel 2.40 GHz RAM: 2048 MB Chrome: Chrome version: 5.0.375.23 r45554 <<<Release>>> QuickTime Player: 7.6.6 QuickTime PlayerX: <unknown> Flash Player: 10.0.45.2 What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Navigate to any chinese page. ie. http://news.cn.yahoo.com/10-04-/1453/2k6g8.html 2. Select some text and do drag 'n drop of selected text from Chrome to TextEdit.app Expected result: 2.1 Dropped text looks like what we have in the browser. Actual result: 2.2 Dropped text gets converted to garbaged text. Note: - Works fine on Mac Safari and Firefox. - We have verified this problem for Chinese and Japanese text.

title.$t: Chrome inaccessible by non-admin user after 2.0.172.6 update

content.$t: Chrome Version : 2.0.172.6 I am on Vista SP1 with UAC. What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Install Chrome as usual 2. Switch to the beta channel, install 2.0.169.1. Everything worked. 3. Today it was auto-update (by Google Update service?) to 2.0.172.6 What is the expected result? Able to run chrome as usual (non-admin). What happens instead? If I run chrome.exe as non-admin nothing happens. If I run it as administrator, Chrome opens as usual. In C:\Program Files\Google\Chrome\Application I see two directories. 2.0.169.1 has read permissions for everyone. 2.0.172.6 has permission only for admin (see screenshots). If I add "Read and execute" permission for my non-admin user (from the "Properties" window of the 2.0.172.6 directory), I am able to run chrome as usual.

title.$t: ChromeFrame: Pick up version number from resources for crash dumps

content.$t:
Currently there's a hard coded version number in the 
google_breakpad::CustomClientInfo* GetCustomInfo(). We need to supply correct 
version (and product etc.) info from the version resource of the DLL. 

This is essential for differentiating crashes per version on the.

title.$t: [MD audit] [Window Sandbox] CrossCallParamsEx::CreateFromBuffer() integer overflow

content.$t:
In src\sandbox\src\crosscall_server.cc there is an integer overflow issue 
with call_params->GetParamsCount()

If the param_count value in the untrusted buffer is above max_uint / 4 or if 
param_count is 0.

The net effect is that we allocate memory from the heap
   backing_mem = new char[actual_size];

In which actual_size is smaller than required by 0x60 bytes. The following 
placement new allocation:
   new(backing_mem)CrossCallParamsEx();

Causes bytes outside the allocated chunk of the heap to be overwritten. I 
does not appear that the values or location are controlled by the attacker, 
in fact they are just zeros form the above ctor.

Unfortunately now the loop that calls 
  address = copied_params->GetRawParameter() 

is now operating in memory that has not been fully initialized. This codepath 
then performs 7 tests on the |address| value which random memory is unlikely 
to pass but one can never be sure.

The severity rating reflects the fact that the bug is in a security sensitive  code-path but I is believed that it would be very hard to exploit this bug 
beyond DoS via heap corruption.

title.$t: Security: Apple QuickTime memory corruption when loading BMP file.

content.$t:
When loading a perfectly normal BMP file, Apple QuickTime suffers from 
memory corruption. This affects all browsers if a webpage can load 
QuickTime.

<BODY onload="setTimeout('location.reload()', 1000);">
  <EMBED src="repro.bmp" type="video/quicktime"></EMBED>
</BODY>

I reported this to Apple product security today. I'll track that discussion 
here:
http://code.google.com/p/skylined/issues/detail?id=11

SecSeverity-Critical because AFAIK, QuickTime is not sandboxed. I have not 
looked at exploitability or bothered to find the root cause - that is 
probably too time consuming, considering I have no symbols or source.

title.$t: Google Chrome XSS through MS Word Script Execution Object
[MD audit] [V8]: integer errors lead to dangerous crashes in memory allocators

content.$t:
Quoting Mark's raw report below.

My notes:
- Definitely SecSeverity-High. If possible, we should sneak a fix into v4.
- I'm surprised this triggers on my x86_64 Linux build. The root cause of 
the integer overflow needs fixing of course -- but if e.g. size_t (64-bit 
on x86_64) had been used for the allocation size, it's unlikely that evil 
JavaScript could cause an integer overflow.

===
1. Javascript (V8) Core Memory Integer Vulnerabilities

File: v8/src/factory.cc
Function: Several
Problem Type: Memory Corruption
Compromise Type: Remote Sandbox Process Compromise
Severity: High

The core memory allocators in the V8 Javascript engine suffer from numerous 
integer overflows and signed-integer related problems. The problematic 
functions are as follows:

Factory::NewFixedArray()
Factory::NewFixedArrayWithHoles()
Factory::NewStringDictionary()
Factory::NewNumberDictionary()
Factory::NewDescriptorArray()

Each of these functions deal with negative size parameters incorrectly at 
lower layers (this will be discussed shortly). Note that each of these 
functions has an ASSERT() statement ensuring the size parameter is greater 
than 0, but these are not compiled in to release versions of Chrome. These 
functions are basically just wrappers to lower level memory allocation 
functions, mainly:

Heap::AllocateFixedArray()
Heap::AllocateFixedArrayWithHoles()
HashTable<Shape, Key>::Allocate()

The two AllocateFixedArray() functions call Heap::AllocateRawFixedArray() 
which contains an integer overflow when multiplying the requested size in 
the call to FixedArray::SizeFor(). It also handles negative integers 
incorrectly (due to how the NewSpace::AllocateRaw() functions work). The 
latter HashTable::Allocate() function has several potential integer 
overflows contained within it - primarily when rounding up the size using 
the EntryToIndex() function. Note that there is also a signed comparison 
issue in this function - for any negative length that is passed to this 
function it will be "rounded up" to 4.

These vulnerabilities can be exploited remotely in at least one place - the 
Runtime_ArrayConcat() function in v8/src/runtime.cc. This function 
implements the Array.concat() function available in Javascript. By 
concatenating numerous large arrays, it is possible to pass any arbitrarily 
large integer of the attacker's choosing the various allocation functions, 
and thus trigger the vulnerabilities. This is subsequently followed by 
copying data of the attacker's choosing past the end of the allocated 
buffer, potentially resulting in remote excution.

A PoC is attached.
===

title.$t: [MD audit] [3d]

content.$t: (Describe security bug here, with as much details and steps to reproduce as possible. Security bugs are visible only to the reporter and to project members.)

title.$t: Security: Popup & Focus URL Hijacking from ha.ckers.org, exploit works with chrome autodownload

content.$t:
I noticed this blog entry
http://ha.ckers.org/blog/20091228/popup-focus-url-hijacking/ at
ha.ckers.org where Rsnake discussed this exploit in context of IE(Firefox
not vulnerable). I found it more interesting with Chrome as chrome has a
auto download function which does not tell which domain the download is
coming from/nor changes the url in any way to indicate different domain. in
this case, the auto downloaded file will appear to come from a ev cert ssl
site which is misleading to a user and can convince user to run a malicious
file. e.g. my evil site showing a link to download trusted software xyz.
when user clicks on link, trusted software xyz site opens and autodownload
starts/prompt appears. user thinks the site is trusted, so saves and run
the malicious file.

Solution: If domain in url and downloaded file are different, user's
download prompt should include domain of the downloaded file.

Test case:
http://ha.ckers.org/weird/ffpopup.html

There is a small message that shows "Waiting for evildomain.xyz",just above
the download bar, but that vanishes almost instaneously, so user is bound
to miss seeing that one.

title.$t: [MD audit] [RPC] More errors deserializing SkBitmaps!!

content.$t:
From Mark:

---
1. Bitmap Row size Desynchronization

File: chrome/common/common_param_traits.cc
Function: ParamTraits<SkBitmap>::Read()
Problem Type: Logic
Compromise Type: Local Escalation
Severity: Medium

ParamTraits<SkBitmap>::Read() allows a largely unchecked SkBitmap_Data 
structure to be used to create an SkBitmap. While the allocPixels() 
function protects 
from integer overflows, it does so by checking that fHeight * fRowBytes do 
not overflow. However, fWidth can be desynchronized from fRowBytes, which 
seems to 
create problems in the privileged process. For example, when the SkBitmap 
is stored in a Thumbnail store (via the ViewHostMsg_Thumbnail message), the 
JPEGCodec encodes the data from the SkBitmap, which does calculations based 
on the images fWidth value, not fRowBytes.

2. Bitmap Information Leak

File: chrome/common/common_param_traits.cc
Function: ParamTraits<SkBitmap>::Read()
Problem Type: Information Leak
Compromise Type: Information Leak
Severity: Medium

ParamTraits<SkBitmap>::Read() seems to allow you to allocate an SkBitmap 
without supplying enough data to fill it. The data buffer it is copied it 
into is 
not zero'd out and so if a small amount of variable data is supplied, the 
remainder of the buffer will contain random data from the process. I am not 
certain 
if this data can be read back from the child host, but I suspect it can 
from a thumbnail database (or possibly by placing it on a HTML canvas).
---

title.$t: [MD audit] [IPC] problems calling resize() on vectors with no sanitization

content.$t:
[Marking as SecSeverity-Low because when I last looked at this, I got 
bad_alloc instead of integer overflow. I can't remember what O/S I tested 
on]

From Mark:

---
IPC Lower Layer

The IPC Lower Layer is the code responsible for marshaling and unmarshaling 
data structures that are passed between different processes over a named 
pipe. Primarily, this consists of the Pickle class as well as the 
ParamTraits<> template classes for each data structure that needs to be 
exchanged. Many of the vulnerabilities here are dependant on whether 
allocation fails throw an exception (bad_alloc), and also whether the STL 
in use protects from integer overflows when sizeof(type) * element_count 
overflows. In general, Microsoft's STLs do but g++ ones don't.

1. Vector Integer Overflow

File: ipc/ipc_message_utils.h
Function: ParamTraits<std::vector<P>>::Read()
Problem Type: Integer Overflow
Compromise Type: Local Escalation
Severity: Medium

The vector::resize() function can result in integer overflows in 
allocations in many STL implementations if the size passed to it multiplied 
by the size of the base type is larger than MAX_UINT. Exploiting this would 
result in memory corruption and thus allow for privilege escalation. One 
such message that utilizes this data type is the 
ViewHostMsg_PasswordFormsSeen sent from the renderer to the browser.

2. Form Field Vector Integer Overflow

File: ipc/ipc_message_utils.h
Function: ParamTraits<webkit_glue::FormFieldValues>::Read()
Problem Type: Integer Overflow
Compromise Type: Local Escalation
Severity: Medium

The vector::resize() function can result in integer overflows in 
allocations in many STL implementations if the size passed to it multiplied 
by the size of the base type (in this case, a FormField object) is larger 
than MAX_UINT. Exploiting this would result in memory corruption and thus 
allow for privilege escalation. 

3. Histogram Integer Overflow

File: base/histogram.cc
Function: Histogram::SampleSet::Deserialize()
Problem Type: Integer Overflow
Compromise Type: Local Escalation
Severity: Medium

The vector::resize() function can result in integer overflows in 
allocations in many STL implementations if the size passed to it multiplied 
by the size of the base type (in this case, an integer) is larger than 
MAX_UINT. Exploiting this would result in memory corruption and thus allow 
for privilege escalation.

4. Histogram Constructor Integer Overflow

File: base/histogram.cc
Function: Histogram::Histogram()
Problem Type: Integer Overflow
Compromise Type: Local Escalation
Severity: Medium

The bucket_count variable is an untrusted integer received from the 
deserialization routine Histogram::DeserializeInfo(). This is then passed 
to SampleSet::Resize(), which simply does a vector resize(), resulting in 
similar problems to those as discussed above.
---

title.$t: sync UI on NTP is broken

content.$t:
when an authentication error occurs (e.g you change your password), the 
NTP receives a message and displays a "re-login" link.  However, this link 
is now (since the new bookmark sync / extensions promo) set up to do 
nothing except show a "Synced to foo@gmail" yellow box at the top of the 
NTP.  The rest of the UI in chrome shows "Bookmark Sync Error", because 
your credentials are actually invalid; clicking this does work as expected.

The problem was caused by 
http://codereview.chromium.org/462011/show.  I (and likely anyone on 
this mail list) had no idea this change took place (the code is pretty visibly 
broken)... No one on sync was cc'ed, partly my fault for not capturing 
new_tab_page_sync_handler.cc in our sync watchlist.

My best fix at the moment is to disable sending any error messages from 
sync to the NTP.  A small pretty easy patch.

title.$t: ValidityState can hold a stale pointer to control

content.$t:
https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=33729

Description From Alexey Proskuryakov 2010-01-15 12:03:42 PST (-) [reply]
ValidityState::m_control is a plain pointer, and nothing guarantees that the
control doesn't go away while ValidityState is reachable. This is likely
exploitable for remote code execution.

This cannot be easily fixed by making m_control a RefPtr, because that would
introduce a reference cycle.

title.$t: Security: Cross-domain bug in password manager

content.$t:
I have not had a lot of time to test various scenarios with this issue.  If
you have trouble reproducing, just let me know and I can try to get a more
precise test case.

In messing around with HTTP digest authentication, I discovered a behavior
where the password manager pre-populates the login form for one domain with
the credentials for *another domain*.  It doesn't submit them
automatically, but does leave the user one click away from sending
credentials to the wrong place.

Here are the steps I followed on Chrome 3.0.195.38 under Windows 7 (release
candidate):

0. Set up an HTML page with the following contents:
   <html><body>
     <img src="http://evil.example.com/image.png" />
   </body></html>

   This page should be hosted at (not protected by any auth):
     http://victim.example.org/test-img.html


1. Next, set up an HTTP digest protected area under the following URL:
   http://victim.example.org/private/


2. Now set up the attacker's server to be digest protected, so 
   that the following URL should prompt for digest auth:
   http://evil.example.com/image.png


3. Log in to a digest-protected area such as: 
   http://victim.example.org/private

   Save the password in the password manager.


4. Now, access the unauthenticated HTML page on the victim's server:
   http://victim.example.org/test-img.html
     
   Since the embedded image requires authentication, you should get a
   password prompt.  

The vulnerability I encountered is that the password manager actually
prepopulates victim.example.org's credentials in this dialog.  In message
board websites, or anywhere that an attacker can post links to images on
third party sites, this could be a serious phishing issue.  No other
browser I tested does this.

With digest authentication, this isn't the end of the world since passwords
aren't that easy to get at, but I would be surprised if basic
authentication prompts don't have the same behavior.

I was doing some general security testing on many browsers when I came
across this issue.  I have some additional observations about security
weaknesses in this area which affect many browsers that I'll be publishing
in a week or so.  I will drop a link somewhere here when I get it out and I
hope some of your devs will have a chance to review it.

thanks!

title.$t: Can't build pyautolib: pyautolib_wrap.cc:870: warning: format not a string literal and no format arguments

content.$t:
cc1plus: warnings being treated as errors
/chrome/trunk/src/chrome/../xcodebuild/chrome.build/DerivedSources/R
elease/pyautolib_wrap.cc: In function 'void 
SWIG_Python_AddErrorMsg(const char*)':
/chrome/trunk/src/chrome/../xcodebuild/chrome.build/DerivedSources/R
elease/pyautolib_wrap.cc:870: warning: format not a string literal and no 
format arguments

pyautolib_wrap.cc:870 is

    PyErr_Format(PyExc_RuntimeError, mesg);

Apparently, PyErr_Format has declared itself to the compiler as using 
printf-style formatting, and the compiler is checking format strings (-
Wformat).  This line should probably be written as

    PyErr_Format(PyExc_RuntimeError, "%s", mesg);

however, pyautolib_wrap.cc is a generated file and I'm not quite sure where 
this problem line comes from.

I'm building against the 10.6 SDK in case that makes a difference.

title.$t: webkit.gyp:pull_in_test_shell is bad

content.$t:
webkit.gyp:pull_in_test_shell is a problem.  The reason: it creates a circular 
relationship between .gyp files.

webkit.gyp:pull_in_test_shell depends on test_shell.gyp.

test_shell.gyp has targets that depend on webkit.gyp.

It doesn't appear that anything actually uses pull_in_test_shell.  At the very 
least, it doesn't need to be part of webkit.gyp.  Perhaps we can put it 
elsewhere, such as all.gyp?

This circular relationship is causing problems for the Mac build.

title.$t: Security: code execution for associated file types

content.$t:
Pre-conditions:
 - (Windows)
 - interpreter such as Python installed
 - file type associated with the interpreter (i.e. double-click icon runs
that code)
 - files served from the server with content type application/octet-stream

1. Find a web page with a file that would be interpreted were it to be
downloaded and then opened
2. Click the link
3. Code runs with no warning prompt.

Expected behaviour:
Either the file should be displayed in the browser (Internet Explorer's
behaviour) or - probably more correctly given the content type - a "Save or
Open" dialog should be shown (as per Firefox).

Chrome's behaviour allows execution of arbitrary code with no warning, this
is a serious bug.

Security: Password Manager

This isn't so much a bug as it is an issue with a feature. In the Options -> 
Personal Stuff -> "Show Saved Passwords" to view your passwords requires a 
single click of a button.

Should someone steal for example a users laptop and open Chrome, not only do 
they have a comprehensive list of emails on which sites the user visited, 
they also contain the Passwords which a cyber attacker may use to commit any 
number of offences. (Think Ebay, gmail, PayPal etc)

I simply propose that a Master password be put in place to view all of these 
passwords. I know the point of these passwords is not to remind you should 
you forget and having a password to view passwords does not seem like a 
clever move, but it is a more secure one.

title.$t: XSS Filter can disable legitimate code, creating vulnerabilities in otherwise safe webpages

content.$t:
To demonstrate I will show a practical attack which opens popular social 
networking website Twitter to a practical Clickjacking attack by abusing 
Chrome's XSS filter.

It is important to note that the attack is not caused by any weaknesses 
coming from Twitter's side, in fact Twitter was chosen specifically because 
of its solid Anti-Clickjacking defenses.

Tested on:
• Browser: Chrome 4.0.249.78 (36714)
• OS: Win7

Pre-conditions:
• Web browser is Chrome
• User is logged into Tweeter

Steps:
1. Go to http://security.tstehle.com/TwitterClickjackingChrome.php?
opacity=30
2. Observe that Twitter is loaded in an iFrame and is not breaking out (as 
it normally would). Also note that the Chrome console says: "Refused to 
execute a JavaScript script. Source code of script found within request."
3. Click on the "DO NOT CLICK" button.
4. Observe that the iFrame does not break out of the parent window, and 
stays at its previous degree of opacity.
5. Go to your Twitter account.
6. Observe that a Twitter post has been made in your name.

Analysis:
When the XSS filter catches suspicious data in the request, it will wait 
for the response and if a script matching the request is about to run the 
script will be disabled. Chrome has no way to know if this code is there as 
a result of an injection or is a legitimate part of the webpage. 
Consequently legitimate code can be disabled. Such code can include frame 
breaking code used to prevent Clickjacking attacks.

The Twitter page which is used in the iFrame for our clickjacking attack is
http://twitter.com/?
%3Cscript%20type=%22text/javascript%22%3E//%3C![CDATA[if%20(window.top%20!=
=%20window.self)%20{document.write%20=%20%22%22;window.top.location%20=%20w
indow.self.location;%20setTimeout(function(){document.body.innerHTML='';},1
);window.self.onload=function(evt){document.body.innerHTML='';};}//]]%3E%3C
/script%3E
The content of Twitter's framebreaking script has been added to the URL as 
a parameter. Chrome detects a potential XSS injection and when the actual 
script is about to execute it will find a match and block it. That match 
obviously happens to be Twitter's legitimate framebreaking script.

Quick Fix for Twitter:
I believe the header "X-XSS-Protection: 0" is not implemented for Chrome, 
meaning that Twitter's easiest fix would be to use "X-Frame-Options: deny". 
Twitter could also set the content of its pages to display:none; and only 
display it if it is not framed. 

Long Term Solution:
Clickjacking is probably not the only weakness which can be created by 
this. Meaning that even if everyone used "X=Frame-Options: deny" (which 
only defends against clickjacking), vulnerabilities would still be created. 
The first step would be to implement "X-XSS-Protection: 0" to give a chance 
to webmasters to opt out.
Honestly, the entire premise of disabling scripts seems flawed from the get 
go. Maybe the real solution would be to copy FireFix plugin NoScript which 
modified the request and not the response, guaranteeing that the response 
is safe.
I will investigate more and get back to you.

On the plus side:
This does not seem anywhere as bad as what IE8's Filter does...

title.$t: Regression in text field autofill security

content.$t:
Seems to be a dev channel regression. I noticed it recently; it's pretty 
blatant.

I'm on Linux 4.0.302.2, but this may have affected earlier versions too.

To reproduce:
- Go to https://mail.google.com/ whilst not logged in.
- (You need to have previously logged in since you last cleared your 
cache).
- Type the first letter of your login name.
- Note how it autocompletes immediately.
- I have verified that this autocompleted value is immediately available to 
evil Javascript using HTMLInputElement.value;
- Also, if the mouse is hovered over other autocomplete suggestions, these 
values seem to immediately be used to populate the input field.

It didn't used to behave this way. We used to require the user to click on 
an autocomplete suggestion before it were leaked to the evil page.

I also worry there may be a way to cause autocomplete without any user 
interaction at all.

I'm not sure whether or not it's a security bug. By the way it's not an

title.$t: DNS prefetch occuring when it shoudn't

content.$t:
Even if your website content is delivered over HTTPS, and you send an "X-
DNS-Prefetch-Control: off" HTTP header, and you add a <meta name="x-
dns-prefetch-control" content="off"> tag to the HTML, <link rel="dns-
prefetch" href="//example.com"> still causes a DNS pre-fetch to take place. 
This will cause problems with displaying user submitted content on websites 
as "text/html" unless such tags are explicitly filtered
from the results.

If DNS prefetching has been explicitly disabled, then the <link rel="dns-
prefetch"> method should not work...

title.$t: Security: LocalStorage Cross Domain Denial of Service Attack

content.$t:
Operating System : Windows XP SP2
Chrome Version : 4.0.249.78

Steps to reproduce :
1. Visit an evil domain which executes a DOS exploit filling up the
localStorage (and probably occupying localstorage ipc channel?) (in an
iframe) - http://securethoughts.com/security/localstorage/exploit.html
2. Wait for some time like 10 sec.
3. Open a new tab and visit a trusted site -
http://infernohacks.com/localstorage/set.html which wants to set a single
name/value pair.
4. Trusted Site won't open. it looks to fail accessing the localStorage.
5. Sites that don't use localStorage open normally. e.g. i tried google.com
and it opened fine.
6. If you close the browser and restart it again, then everything works fine.

(step 3 must be done after step 1, otherwise step 4 might work as expected
since it might get cached.)

i also found this to show the same result for Mac OS Snow Leopard + Chrome
4.0.302.2 dev

title.$t: document.domain can be set to a tld

content.$t:
Webkit bug unfixed reported by me in 2008-10-02 so you should patch while 
webkit doesn't
https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=21318
This is still unfixed in Chrome 4.

document.domain can be set to a tld. So if an iframe does 
document.domain='com'; any embedding webpage can do the same thing and do 
XSS easily.
You should validate if a tld is a tld using the publicsuffix list, for 
instance http://publicsuffix.org/

For instance the capitalone website did that some time ago out of ignorance
http://my.opera.com/community/forums/findpost.pl?id=2749451
An iframe embedding that page like <iframe src="https://capitalone.com/"></
iframe> would be able to do xss in chrome easily.

title.$t: Personal passwords

content.$t:
It is too easy to access to personal passwords under Options/Personal 
Staff/Show saved passwords. Namely in only few seconds I may be able to 
access to this exclusive information while owner of the personal computer 
is not under my shoulder. Maybe it seems uncommon but people are using 
computers owned and managed by other very often, sometimes for few minutes 
sometimes even longer. I am not comfortable to borrow my computer for 1 
minute if I am aware of risk that the borrower could access to my personal 
passwords (or I will turn to other web browser). Also, it is very tempting 
not to access this section when you use other person's computer.

In conclusion "saved password option" is generally more than useful in fact 
necessary but the access to the passwords should be somehow protected (by 
password or in other way - I am not an engineer but lawyer).

eip = 5f657275 esp = 0012efa8 ebp = 0012efd8 iopl = 0 nv up ei pl nz na pe 
nc
cs = 001b ss = 0023 ds = 0023 es = 0023 fs = 003b gs = 0000 efl = 00010206
5f657275?????
0:000 "u poi (ESP)-b poi (ESP)
chrome_1c30000! ChromeMain +0 x2b5f6d:
01ee91f9 8b10 mov edx, dword ptr [eax]
01ee91fb 53 push ebx

title.$t: Security: a same site is saved on the saved passwords and exceptions lists

content.$t:
Description:
If a website login page is accessible through both HTTP and HTTPS 
protocols, the website is registered on the saved passwords and exceptions 
list at the same time, what looks odd since the user has 2 excluding 
options: save password or never save password. To me, the browser should 
consider the 2 URL's as a same site (for example: 
http://webmail.cesar.org.br/ and https://webmail.cesar.org.br/). See 
attached images.  

Testing Environment:
Windows 7 Professional 
Google Chrome 4.0.249.78

Pre-condition:
Make sure you have never accessed this website before, neither through HTTP 
nor HTTPS and that there is no cache or saved passwords / exceptions for 
this website.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open Google Chrome.
2. Access the website URL through HTTP.
3. Login. 
4. Choose to save the password (my version in Portuguese says “Salvar 
senha”).
5. Logout.
6. Access the website URL through HTTPS.
7. Login 
8. Choose to not save the password (my version in Portuguese says “Nunca 
para este site”).
9. Access the website URL through HTTP again.

Expected Results vs Results Obtained:
- Step 7 should not have happened since the user had already been asked, in 
step 4, if he/she wanted to save the password or not. He/she should not 
have been asked twice.

title.$t: Automatic Downloads without user prompt

content.$t:
Simple javascript document.write embed's a new iframe into an html 
document. If the source of the iframe is an execeutable, a tar, or another 
file that does not fall under the heading of filetypes that the chrome 
browser opens itself (i.e. html, gif, mp3, etc...) the file is downloaded 
automatically to the user's machine without a prompt for their consent.

This is only really dangerous if it used to upload disguised malware to a 
users machine which they subsequently execute, compromising their 
system.

Attatched is a simple html file which, when loaded, begins an automatic 
download. This version simply uploads a copy of the linux kernel source 
code to the users machine.

A clever hack artist could disguise a malware program and fool a user into 
launching it.

Good will to the chromium team!

title.$t: Security Truth In Advertising Google/Chrome/GMail Bug

content.$t:
Use of the Google/Chrome browser in combination with Google/GMail homepage presents consistent security bugs which can easily be thwarted although 
Google/Chrome/Gmail has yet to take steps to do so

(a) Google/Chrome users who don't install WOT have no way of knowing 
whether or not clicking on a Google ad on their Gmail page is likely to 
lure the user to an unsecure website where waiting malware/spyware etc can 
infect the user's PC

alternately,

(b)Chrome users who do install WOT can clearly see that clicking on certain 
Google Ad links on their GMail page are in fact high security risks, giving 
them mixed signals as to the security commitment of Google/Chrome/GMail 
itself and/or the enterprose's ability/willingness to use available 
security apps providing WOT protection itself to weed out unsecure 
advertisers from secure ones before accepting their business...and 
Google/Chrome/GMail take no responsibility for such lack of security 
resulting in resulting security bug risks such as keystroke logging or ID 
theft

(c) No AdBlockers (or combination thereof)offered by Google/Chrome from 
developers will completely block these insecure Google GMail ads, whether 
by design or built-in security bugs within themselves

(d) Even forearmed with WOT and Adblockers, Chrome browser users can still 
accidentally click on ads leading the browser to allow their GMail page to 
link them to unsecure locations putting them at security bug risks 
mentioned above.

--registered Chrome browser/GMail user

title.$t: Security: cookies modification through javascript injection

content.$t:
Description:
Cookies can be modified through the injection of javascript code on the
address bar. See attached image.

Testing Environment:
Windows 7 Professional 
Google Chrome 4.0.249.78

Pre-condition:
None.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open Google Chrome.
2. Paste the following piece of code on the address bar, on a same line:
   "javascript:void(document.cookie="authorization=true");
    javascript:alert(document.cookie);"
3. Press ENTER.

Expected Results vs Results Obtained:
- No javascript code should be executed from the address bar, although not
only it can be executed to alert the cookies contents, but also to modify
it, like the "authorization" property was modified in the example above.

title.$t: Security: HTML forms modification through javascript injection

content.$t:
Description:
HTML forms can be entirely modified through the injection of javascript
code on the address bar. See attached image.

Testing Environment:
Windows 7 Professional 
Google Chrome 4.0.249.78

Pre-condition:
None.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open Google Chrome.
2. Load Google's web page.
3. Paste the following piece of code on the address bar:
   "javascript:void(document.forms[0].q.size="150");"
4. Press ENTER.
5. Paste the following piece of code on the address bar:
   "javascript:void(document.forms[0].q.value="modify google's code");"
6. Press ENTER.
7. Paste the following piece of code on the address bar:
   "javascript:void(document.forms[0].btnG.type="reset");"
8. Press ENTER.

Expected Results vs Results Obtained:
- No javascript code should be executed from the address bar, however 
Google's main webpage forms HTML source code, for example, can be entirely
modified through the injection of many different lines.
